At times, Professor Lee can be kind of dry, but she is great at leading discussions and providing specific feedback. She makes time to sit down and work with every student outside of class and also works to accommodate students to the best of her ability.

Took Syntax I with Prof. Legendre. Very knowledgeable and passionate in linguistics. She cares about her students: very accessible and patient during class/office hours and would spend time in class going over the assignments. Syntax is HARD and get ready to spend tons of time --- don't take it unless you are really interested.

Took Syntax I with Prof. Legendre. Very knowledgeable and passionate in linguistics. She cares about her students: very accessible and patient during class/office hours and would spend time in class going over the assignments. Syntax is HARD and get ready to spend tons of time --- don't take it unless you are really interested.

She was passionate but doesn't know how to teach introductory level material: no one understood the rules and people fell quickly behind. Homeworks are above our comprehension level for an introductory course, and take up to 10 hours a week. Do not take this course if you want an easy class or something that will not stress you out.
She is one of the most passionate teachers that I ever had. Her classes are not easy, but if you try, you will do well. I love her!!

Prof Legendre has such a passion for her work and linguistics and she definitely brought that passion to class. The content in the class is fairly complex and most people seemed to LOVE class or HATE it, there wasn't much in between. I would definitely recommend to anyone  interested in how languages work but definitely NOT an "easy N credit".

Hands down, one of the best professors I have had and will have! Extremely helpful, might appear strict at first but is very easy going and warm. Takes interest in student's performance and knows her subject in and out. Highly recommend taking WOL with her!
Great Professor. When Needed help she was readily available. TA's are helpful. Great class very interesting. Just dont allow yourself to fall behind. Alot of material

Professor Leheny is a really interesting and cool professor. He tries to make the class interactive and fun and succeeds in large part. I felt that the way he teaches alongside the style of the classroom to encourage discussion with our peers leads to a very helpful and successfully didactic environment.

Professor Leheny is a really interesting and cool professor. He tries to make the class interactive and fun and succeeds in large part. I felt that the way he teaches alongside the style of the classroom to encourage discussion with our peers leads to a very helpful and successfully didactic environment.

Physics 1 is a really hard class, but having Leheny as a prof definitely helped a lot. He's a very nice guy and quite approachable, you just have to ask. He also has a really good sense of humor and finds clever ways to simplify physics into something more digest able. If you have to take physics and you have the chance, go with Leheny.

Good person, teaching style just did not work for me at all. Could have not gone to lecture at all because they were no help if you didn't understand the prelectures. Written homework was hell on earth and nothing like what we did in class. Exam format and grading were just horrible in terms of consistency and relevance to class work.

He's really a professor that's there for his students; perfectly willing to take extra time for any problems you might have, and even organizes class lunches at the beginning of the semester. Physics is tough in general, so the quality of the professor matters, and Prof. Leheny will go the extra mile for a student. BTW, you will need a clicker.
Great professor, had him for 2 courses and he genuinely enjoys physics and is a really good teacher

Physics II for Engineers (neuro major) - Leheny is awesome, and makes jokes during lecture to keep things interesting. By no means an easy class but as great as a physics class can be. Lecture isn't exactly mandatory but there are clicker question which count toward your grade. Leheny is a cool guy and it was a good class overall.
The most enjoyable class I've taken so far in college. Leheny is hilarious, especially when he reminisces, and it's clear he loves physics. HE'S DA BOMB!!!
loved going to lecture. Loved watching the cool demos. really cool guy in general.

Leheny is very enthusiastic and a great explainer of physics, which is important because he teaches electromagnetics, which can be very abstract.  He relates the material to real-world applications. The homework is very doable and very helpful for the tests.  I highly recommend taking physics 2 with Leheny!

Leheny is a pretty awesome professor. He doesn't depend on PP, but his lessons are very organized.  He always seems excited to teach, is pretty funny and isn't afraid to make fun of himself. Cool demonstrations, tests are fair and related to the lecture. The only thing I wished for was a better TA.
Difficult material. Pretty fair course.

Lecture can be boring but is usually okay. Sign up for 10:30 if you can. Tests are very fair. He really enjoys teaching and obviously loves the subject. Extremely clear, wants students to answer questions, and he will answer thoroughly if a question comes up. Pretty funny guy, too.
The class was incredibly difficult. Success means a lot of studying - not simply showing up to class. He's a nice guy though. Approachable and funny.
Theoretical > Computational "Conceptual, engaging... um... also he has good sense of humor"

Didn't make you feel like an idiot if you ask him to explain an integral or something. Worth coming to class-- explains in a thorough and well-organized way. Straightforward tests, isn't trying to kill us on the homework either, a first around here.

Leheny's a pretty nice prof. Lectures are usually helpful for homeworks and tests, but he is somewhat boring except for demos and a couple of jokes here and there. Handwriting is fair. Exams are pretty easy and straightforward, just make sure you pay attention in class and know the material. Curves generously.

Would be an engaging guy if he weren't incredibly self-involved.  Not interested in hearing anyone else talk but himself.  Grades very harshly, on some level to help students improve, but its clear he gets off on giving back terrible grades.

It's clear that Prof. Leithauser knows his material, and his thoughts on literature are thoughtful and profound.  Still, his tone and choice of readings can be rather dry, which makes long classes with him hard to sit through.

Professor Leps is one of the best professors Ive ever had. Although Accounting can be dry, she takes the time to make sure everyone understands the material by involving class participation. Shes very receptive to questions and clarifications without judgement. Very fair problem sets and exams, & very light HW load if you pay attention in class.

Professor Leps is one of the best professors Ive ever had. Although Accounting can be dry, she takes the time to make sure everyone understands the material by involving class participation. Shes very receptive to questions and clarifications without judgement. Very fair problem sets and exams, & very light HW load if you pay attention in class.
NOT EVEN FOLLOW the Syllabus. Handout is absolutely out of date and HURT your eyes so much, and the hand written notes are SUPER hard to follow.
Good prof, Financial Accounting is boring.
She's the best. I wish she could teach other Hopkins professors how to be approachable and make the subject matter interesting.
Best professor at Hopkins
Great professor. Really friendly and engaging. Doesn't just lecture but leads interesting class discussions.

The provided lecture materials were so good, I probably didn't need the textbook. The demo videos were essential because I was new to R studio commands. Office hour videos were very helpful! Grade included weekly discussions & homework, monthly homework set and quiz, 2 short exams, 2 group projects (ugh), and a huge final exam.

Probably not the place to mention this but I completed Dr Lessick's bioinformatics course through Coursera.  He took time to answer questions in forums, gave very clear lectures and was most helpful.  I would certainly consider taking his classes if I went to JHU, or through coursera if not.
Good teacher, lectures were great, presents the material in a clear and interesting manner. woukd take classes from him again. Dont need the textbook, pretty easy class.

My first bioinformatics class. The class was interesting.  I am not a computer person so I was often one of the last people to leave. I left the class with a good understanding and I refer to his lectures often when performing searchs. Not to stressfull,no homework,clear material,take good notes. Open note exams/quizes. I often recomment his class.
One of the better teachers I've had so far.  Classes are clear cut, teaches material well and in a visual hands-on manner.  Nice guy, and I think his classes are pretty easy.
Work through a lot of homework problems, but in the end it helps.

Amazing professor! The department is small, so the class was full of students from other majors. He really cares about his students & expects participation in class. Best to be prepared. Some overlap in material with his other classes. Quizzes & tests are fairly easy if you pay attention :) Charismatic & very passionate about the subject

Amazing professor! The department is small, so the class was full of students from other majors. He really cares about his students & expects participation in class. Best to be prepared. Some overlap in material with his other classes. Quizzes & tests are fairly easy if you pay attention :) Charismatic & very passionate about the subject

One of the best professors at Hopkins He really cares about his students and is willing to work with you His lectures are amazing and draw from the readings but with a lot of added material, so definitely don't miss class if you can avoid it He really appreciates student involvement in class and expects participation Tests & quizzes are sorta easy

Amazing lectures, little to no homework, manageable readings and frequent gradebook entries. Fantastic professor and person. You have to show up for class though because he introduces new material in lecture A LOT
Friendly, good-natured, generally concerned about the students and their views, and offers a nuanced, broad overlook on some of the more controversial topics.  Taking his class has been a pleasure.
No Comments

This guy curves to a C or C-. Don't take his class. Got 20 points above average and got a B. That makes no sense. Planning on making a complaint. Do a ton of practice problems and you'll do well. Most students can't understand his english, so most did not come to class or dropped his class for the engineering one, which was the best idea to do.
No grading criteria. Takes off 20 marks just because he couldn't understand your method of solving and won't discuss it with you. Doesn't like being asked questions and is aggravated easily.

He skips over slides and expects you to understand without fully solving equations. He grades hw badly and he expects things he never mentions in class. Dont discuss why he butchered it he'll fight with you and don't bother going to him during office hours, he will degrade you to your grave. Don't take this class. He doesn't teach at all.
Elementary materials. You can take this course online.
Communication is a major problem. Hold on subject material is dubious
Pl don't waste your precious time by taking this class
Zhan Li was actually my favorite professor so far!
Straightforward, explains the material without being too technical and in-depth about theorem and proofs. Need textbook for homework problemsets.

This class is fine if you spend the mental effort associated with keeping up with the professor as he speaks. The accent and handwriting can be a bit difficult to work through at times however. Otherwise, he is a fine professor.

This class is fine if you spend the mental effort associated with keeping up with the professor as he speaks. The accent and handwriting can be a bit difficult to work through at times however. Otherwise, he is a fine professor.
Took her for linear algebra, She is by far the nicest professor in the math department, she told us she would give out as many A's as possible - and she lived up to that promise!

He gave interesting lectures which always included current news stories. The papers and exams allowed you to pick your own topic, so you could choose what you felt most passionate about. Great professor who cares about how much you learn rather on what grade you get. Best professor on campus!
Best teacher I've had at Hopkins. She's so good I actually bothered to go on this website to inform people.
The class it tough, but she really cares that students do well. She's approachable, understanding, and dedicated. One of the best professors I've had at Hopkins.
Truly a funny, funny woman. In a good way... but slightly difficult to take seriously while learning tones.
I love her. You can tell she really loves teaching, and she does it really well. :)
Nice lady, does accept things late, cares about students.
Good teacher. Explains things clearly. Cares about students.
nice old lady, accepts late homework often, perky
We all love our bafken

The Buddhist Experience is the best class at this school! Completely changed my perception of the world. Bavo is a fabulous and caring professor who teaching with clarity and gusto. He is always willing to help and aid in your understanding of the material. His enthusiasm for the subject is contagious. Pretty high work load however.

Intro to Buddhism - Mind opening class, Bavo is adorable and helpful and very enthusiastic, makes class much better. I'm not a morning person so the 1030 slot does tire me out sometimes given that its all lecture, but the class is TOTALLY worth it, the workload is a lot with reading but if youre interested you will do well on the papers for sure.
Open your mind

Professor Lievens was very clear and taught with great enthusiasm and interest. Take all his courses.
No in depth knowledge of subject matter, too much self promotion
Often doesn't know the subject matter in depth.

Professor Liew should be really goood at selling insurance. He talks irrelevant junk all the time in the lecture. However, that is the real world about, talking rubbish,  be cunning and earned money from innocent but stupid people. So his class is actually helpful.
he is a genius that we can not follow him
Great Professor. Highly Recommended
Prof. Liew is the best professor in the world. Period. I have taken a few courses with him and I always learned more than what's expected. He brought inspiration, vision and passion to the class.
Very nice guy. However, the class doesn't live up to its potential. Focused more on salesmanship than the actual work of hedge fund managers/analysts.
Best Professor at Carey
One of the best professors I've had the privilege of meeting. Definitely take him if you're interested in a career in finance

Lightner teaches Radioactive Waste Management at Hopkins EP program. He's very knowledgeable about the everything radiation and his lectures are so interesting, as are the readings he assigns! There are both individual & group HW assignments each week, and an individual as well as a group project - it's time consuming. Definitely cite EVERYTHING.

He was a wonderful teacher, probably my favorite professor I had as an undergrad. The class was a review on single var calc, but he turned it into a wonderful introduction to pure math. We wrote proofs and demonstrated them. He's insanely funny and weird in the best way. Every class was a joy! He always made sure that you understood the material.

He was a wonderful teacher, probably my favorite professor I had as an undergrad. The class was a review on single var calc, but he turned it into a wonderful introduction to pure math. We wrote proofs and demonstrated them. He's insanely funny and weird in the best way. Every class was a joy! He always made sure that you understood the material.
Made class interesting and exciting although made many small mistakes that had to be corrected when writing on the board that was occasionally confusing.  We had a class fish Sfin though!
Outstanding Professor. Brilliant but accessible. Super hipster.

If you engage, participate and are a self starter with an independent approach you will do just fine. Professor will not spoon feed you. He will lead you to the water, but you must dive in. Read, complete the assignments and express opinions. The take always are worth the investment.

This guy likes to hear the sweet sweet sound of his own voice. He told you what grade you were going to get in the syllabus before you even set foot in his class.  Your fate is predetermined.   He leaves everything up to his TA Alison and she never says a word in class.

I don't recommend, he likes to create confusion by putting trick questions or giving an ambiguous explanation. He thinks he is helping but is making u confused. He is not easily approachable,emails back after 2 days. Has no interest if you learn or you struggle. This is not how you teach or develop interest in a student

What a great course. Probably the best biology course I've taken in my life. Dr. Lochamy teaches you HOW to think, not just WHAT to think. Any professor can point to a text and repeat the quotes, but it's rare to find someone who teaches you how to think as a biologist. He will make you work for it, but it's worth it for the learning experience.

Dropped in 3rd week to make room for harder course. Jonathan is personable and knowledgeable on the subject. Started a week early and asked students to do 2 weeks in one, led to confusing organization. Materials are good for learning subject. Quizzes are full of gotchas not answered by materials. Won't admit fault when questions are ambiguous.
Dr. Logsdon is a caring advisor and competent lecturer. While she can be a bit strict, she puts effort into making her courses engaging and relevant to the medical device industry.
Dr. Logsdon is a caring advisor and competent lecturer. While she can be a bit strict, she puts effort into making her courses engaging and relevant to the medical device industry.

Extremely fickle. Gives advice that directly contradicts her grading. Is basically never present, and doesn't bother to meet with the team or show up to committee meetings. Not really sure who let this lab manager be an instructor for this course, especially when she has given absolutely no semblance of competence at any point in the semester.

I came into BME really interested in devices, industry, and Design Team, but her course ruined it for me. Her expectations are unclear, she is extremely unresponsive and generally unavailable. Grades very tough, but doesn't give any individual help to teams (hasn't even made an attempt to get to know us on a personal level). Overall terrible prof.
Dr. Logsdon gives really unclear feedback and has very subjective grading. She gives mixed feedback and doesn't add any value to this course for the position of power that she has in the course.

One of the worst professors I've had. She is usually not around, and when she is she is very unhelpful. Almost completely nonresponsive to emails and gives terribly confusing feedback on your projects. Expectations are unclear and grades highly subjectively. Stay away from this course, because while the idea of the class is great, this professor ru

He cares about the work and assigns readings that give you multiple perspective on complex issues. You'll learn a lot; he's invested in improving your writing.

He's hands down the best prof for MTH161 at UoR. His lectures are clear and it is very easy to take notes in a systematic manner for his class. Don't look at my grade, my session had the hardest exams ever for this course!

Lorman is one of the best calculus teachers here at Rochester and definitely the best MTH 161 teacher. He always asks if anyone needs clarification and explains concepts well. Very accessible outside and in classroom. Kinda funny too. Definitely take his class. He is a fair grader to say the least.

I had Lorman for Calc II for bio which is known for being the harder Calc II class at Hopkins. Lorman did a really great job of teaching complex topics in a way that is pretty easy to understand, even if you don't love math. He's a super nice guy and definitely wants to see his students succeed. Tests are manageable if you study.

I took Honors Single Variable Calculus with him.  He is one of the most caring professors I have and never judges you for having trouble with the material. He made extra office hours and class hours when students requested it and was always available to anyone who needed extra help.  The material was extremely difficult but he graded very fairly.

Amazing professor. Clearly cares a lot about his students' well beings, and is always available to make sure everyone understands the material through and through. Also treats math like its an art form, which makes the class much more enjoyable.
Lurhmann is the light of my life. He is the personification of a ray of sunshine. I am not monotone man.
Lurhmann is the light of my life. He is the personification of a ray of sunshine. I am not monotone man.

Good professor with very structured lectures. Don't necessarily need to attend class if you have a good TA (try to get Matthew White). Slides are organized but new additions to equations added each time so you don't know what the newest full idea is sometimes. An easy course at Hopkins due to large curve from a professor who means well.

Maccini is a good guy and means well, has some humor. Very considerate of the group and therefore moves a slow pace, which is perfectly fine. He loves economics and that helps make the class more interesting. Its not hard, would be nice if there were fewer students.

Weird, both in a good and a bad way. Material is very easy, and he moves at a very slow pace, but sometimes doesn't cover all the details while spending half the lecture on something that everyone knows. Exams are okay, but the questions can be extremely confusing and the grading is very subjective.

Maccini is fine. He moves at an excruciatingly slow pace. We didn't even come close to covering international trade. I guess he had to cater to the lowest common denominator i.e. jocks. The grading can be arbitrary and the questions are notoriously vague. They'll always bite you in the ass for not giving a definition that they didn't ask for.
Elements of Macro.  Class is easy, we didn't go through all of the material by the end of the class.
Maccini's a fine professor. Very clear, and has a subtle sense of humor. And he looks like Emperor Palpatine on Star Wars.
This professor is awesome! You will definitely get out of this class what you put in. Professor Madsen is hilarious and helpful. Career class was always fun.
My favorite teacher in the counseling department so far.  Very energetic, helpful, approachable.  He has a great sense of humor and makes class fun, and you also learn a lot.  Highly recommended.

Amazing teacher..really helpful couse for anyone who ever wants to get a job anywhere...really helpful..funny...hard grader but very fair tells you what he expects..an added plus if u take his class he will offer you his counseling services once you complete his course....such a benifit he is great at what he does!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Lectures are rushed and somewhat shallow even for complicated material. Homework assignments are huge, though not too complicated. While the exam is crazy with suspicious grading. I do regret taking this course. He must be a good researcher, but teaching is simply not his cup of tea.
So great. Super intelligent, loves his material, and is an enthusiastic teacher. Wish they were all like this.
I think Maguire was an excellent prof for the intro class. He was clear and he was truly interested in the material.
Awesome prof, great lectures, fair exams
very knowledgable, good lecturer
Maguire rocks! he's super intelligent and very into what he's teaching. his english accent is adorable and he gets so excited when people laugh at his jokes. i definitely recomend him as a teacher.

His homework and midterms are extremely difficult and he doesn't do a very good job teaching.  I stopped attending his class back in september because his lectures didn't teach me anything at all.  His TA's this year were much more helpful than he was.

His homework and midterms were impossible.  Final was hard too.  He was an awful teacher.  He spent all class doing proofs that we didn't need to know.  I was lucky that I had a good TA, tutor at the learning den and textbook.  He was quite amusing.  Nice butterfly shirt!
No Comments

Nice guy but got grumpy a lot. Exams were ok because he gave us a lot of the problems (with general aspects of them changed), but unfair because they were out of 20 points! Homework was kinda hard at times and the final was so ridiculous. He did end up massively curving the course though so that was ok. I wish him the best in his endeavors!

I liked how a lot of the class focused on figuring out how to use different DL libraries. I had never really thought of that as an important skill until I took the course, but now I see how valuable that is and am glad to have some experience in this area. I also liked how the class was application-based, but still summarized the important points.
He taught a really amazing intersession course on deep learning. I loved the style, the case-based approach was new to me but I learned a lot.

I was really hesitant abou this professor because of these reviews, but it was a decent class. PROS: a lot of mini and fun assignments due every week that actually allows you to apply the material (he's really generous on grading) CONS: The Quizzes ARE WAY TOO SPECIFIC/ YOU HAVE TO REALLY READ THE TEXTBOOK. The Final wasn't so bad. Give him a try!

Professor Mahr is very disorganized. He misses posting assignments on time, yet does not give you extra time to complete them. He tells you to both use and not use outside sources for reference, expecting you to learn from wikipedia or your own searches. Low quality teaching, do not recommend.

The professor is scattered and the weekly assignments are different activities every week. I spend more time reading the instructions than doing the assignments. No exams but there are weekly quizzes. The quizzes are based on the textbook and rarely on lectures. The class was wasn't difficult but the tedious. There's always things to do each week.

Dr. Mahr is scattered. His instructions for assignments warns against spelling and grammatical errors. Yet his communications were riddled with them. It made figuring out what topics are important for tests and quizzes a challenge. Don't expect feedback. That said, he grades fairly and transparently. He's personable in his lectures and emails.

Petar is great! He gave us so much extra credit and his problem sets were actually pretty interesting at times. It's a pretty difficult subject to understand, but the TA's were always very helpful and Petar also had office hours. He even offered to meet with me outside of his office hours once because I was struggling on a concept.

Petar does not take the time in his lectures to ask if the students understand the material. He is a great professor.
Petar is awesome.

I love this guy! He was so caring all throughout the semester and will actually listen to you, stay over time to make sure you understand everything. Going to his office hours was the best choice ever! If you have to take physics take it with Petar
Great teacher, I always enjoyed his lectures and found him very inspirational

This was a difficult class, but only because E&M is a difficult subject. Petar went out of his way to be availible to help students, and wanted everyone to be able to understand the subject and do their best. He put a lot of time and effort into grading fairly, and really cares about teaching.

Petar is an awesome professor. He clearly loves physics and loves teaching. Petar is always available for help. Lectures can be all over the place at times, but in general, lectures are very useful. Petar isn't a particularly difficult professor. Rather, the subject matter is what is difficult. Petar's tests are fair and based off lectures.
Lectures are mainly proofs and derivations that are not useful to the material.

NOTE: Though the people below are correct in saying his class is not easy, his curve is very generous (prob to an A- or so).                                                                                   Very funny, helpful, and genuinely interested in your understanding the material.
I had Petar for classical mechanics I and he was an amazing professor. always available for help.  although the exams were hard, he was very generous.

Petar is an amazing and enthusiastic professor.  He really cares about his students' understanding, and though his exams are ridiculously difficult, he is the ALWAYS available for extra help, if you want it.
Very accessible and supportive, but doesn't always give as helpful of feedback as some of the other design team faculty members. Not as great as other reviews would suggest.

Congratulations on his School of Engineering wide, Dean's Teaching Excellence Award, as well as being nominated by the Career Center as the students' "Career Champion" all on his first year of teaching! well-deserved. We wish we were able to clone Dr. Manbachi so that we had more faculty caring about us on the departmental level.

One of the highest human qualities is COMPASSION which is hard to see around in competitive places. Dr. Manbachi is one of the faculty who has kept up with his compassion and one of the few with high emotional intelligence plus the urge for mentorship / nurturing. Out of all the BME faculty I have had, I have felt the most comfortable with him.

Literally the best professor ever! When I have worked with other professors in the past, they rarely remember my name and sometimes do not even recognize me. On the other hand, Dr. Manbachi, even with his many obligations (especially as a new member of the faculty), still cared about us to an extent that he was going above and beyond his duties.

wow! He offers a business communication skills workshop during the intersession and his "mastering the art of pitching" lecture is must-have for every student with entrepreneurial interests . He is natural and yet humble: I have been taking his design course for a year and didn't realize that in his spare time, he is an awesome serial entrepreneur.

He makes me feel like I matter, and that our projects are valuable. He champions his students and sees them as people. His enthusiasm is contagious. He goes out of his way to help his students. His criticism is extremely helpful, he gets us to see all parts of our project that we'd rather ignore. The best professor I've had the honor to work with.

Dr. Manbachi has a way of making his lectures super fun. His kick-off lecture was a hackathon and his course wrap-up was a jeopardy competition that engaged us in an exciting fashion. For his class on ideation, he had TAs role-play on a number of scenarios about how NOT to brainstorm! Overall, the most memorable lectures of my undergrad experience

Awesome prof! perhaps one of the best I have ever had. He is inspirational, sees the big picture well and always connects us to his close clinical collaborators and industry partners. Without him it was really hard to get answers from clinicians for our capstone design projects. I look up to him as an energetic role model and wanna become like him.

Dr. Manbachi is an inspirational, young, hot prof who is well-connected and respected in the surgical community. Every time the need came up, he put us in touch with clinicians easily, and the surgeons were excited to work with us. He gives great technical advice when it comes to prototyping, usability studies, patentability and entrepreneurship.

The most inspiring, yet humble & caring prof I have ever seen. He brings an unparalleled background to our course (e.g. his own start up, Canada's Inventor of the year, industrial experience in Germany, Harvard post-doc) yet he is so caring, and goes above & beyond to help us. Spends time outside the class & we feel most comfortable around him.
He may come off a little cantankerous, but I'd be hard pressed to think of a teacher who cared more about his students and subject.  He treats you like an adult.
Best teacher I have ever had, will ever have. More than a professor, a mentor, a confidant, a friend.  The reason why the JHU film program is the best one out there.
Greatest teacher at Hopkins hands down.
No Comments

Hands down, Mao is the best professor that I've had at JHU. His eloquence can be intimidating at first, but once you talk with him, you realize how friendly he is and how much he genuinely cares about his students. His classes are work heavy, but he  will go out of his way to give you any help or extensions you need.

It is very rare that I am astounded by a teacher. But I am completely, utterly astonished by Prof. Mao. Each of his phrases are colored by acute insight, and he tosses off pithy bits of eloquence like nothing. He is incisive and brilliant; he adores words. More importantly, however, he is kind, generous, and one of the best teachers I've ever had.

Great professor--a bit of an intellectual snob, but you can't say he doesn't deserve it. He's basically been employed, educated or tenured by every top university in the US, and JHU is lucky to have him. I enjoyed all of his classes, and he really helped open my eyes to what criticism is and how to write it. Emphasizes the importance of good ideas

Prof. Maouelainin is amazing!! She's passionate, funny, patience and smart. The way she teaches stimulates your curiosity and really makes the lecture interesting. She gives good feedback and is always reachable whenever via email or during office hours. Come to class prepared and be open to the class, I guarantee you'll learn a lot and get an A!
BEAUTIFUL,AMAZING,HAPPY,GREAT,ETC. SHE LOVES HER JOB AND U CAN TELL- WORK INVOLVED, BUT WELL WORTH IT TO SEE HER SMILE WHEN U GET IT RIGHT

Good professora!Participated in the class, she will give you a good grade.The quiz is not that hard,all you have to remember is the grammar. She is very fair to every student in her classroom, answer every single question patiently.Take her class even you have nothing known about Spanish before, you will still  learn a lot.

She is a great teacher, makes the class interesting. She keeps you engaged. She is really fair, and very reasonable. I recommend her class. You will learn alot. After a few weeks in get class your level of Spanish will increase.
Nice class
Nice class
excellent

Awesome teacher. Despite the vast breadth of the class she does a great job of focusing on the most important things you need to know to succeed in a physics career. Very upbeat, smart and caring professor. Thoroughly enjoyed her class.
Great professor. Clear explanations and interesting material.
This professor was very enthusiastic but a very hard grader. She makes silly jokes and assigns readings that are almost cryptic and difficult to understand.
Professor Marra is fun, educational, and overall and amazing engineering professor.
Professor Marra is fun, educational, and overall and amazing engineering professor.
Prof. Marra is awesome.

Professor Marra teaches all of the Mechanical engineering labs at Hopkins, as well as several other core courses that vary by semester.  All mechanical engineers will have him for multiple classes, and that isn't a bad thing at all.  Lectures are varied and engaging, and you can always stop by his office for help.

One of the best professors I've had here. He's won a ton of teaching awards and it's easy to see why. He's approachable, engaging, funny, and cares a lot about all of the students. He knows almost every name in my 67-person class.
Great teacher that is passionate and wants you to succeed.
Awesome professor!
Amazing, very clear, very passionate about what he teaches. A great guy, also quite funny.
Nice. Conversations with the Earth was easy. Guided Tour of the Planets was harder than expected.
Freshman Seminar: Conversation with the Earth.

The class was Conversations with Earth, a freshmen seminar. Mostly, I never got to hear the professor lecture. He left it to TAs and guest speakers, but when he did come in, he was enthusiastic. He made sure everyone understood the material and he added humor to it. He really did try hard in his lectures. He's very approachable and friendly.
No Comments
This guy is pretty funny and makes the best of dry material.
Very nice, but dry....

I took History of Occidental Civilization: Europe and the Wider World with Marshall. He's an AMAZING lecturer! He has excellent flow.  He is a seasoned professor and does an excellent job linking between events of a period to give you a feel for what was going on at the time. I highly recommend him!
Interesting class, not bad.  Sometimes lectures can be dry.  He just lectures.  TA sessions can be annoying.
Easy to follow by putting his notes up on the board, though paper topics tended to be hard.

Dr Marshburn knows his stuff. He has a gift for explaining math concepts in a way that you can understand. He's always willing to give extra help. And never makes you feel like your questions aren't valid. I would definitely take more of his classes.

Dr Marshburn knows his stuff. He has a gift for explaining math concepts in a way that you can understand. He's always willing to give extra help. And never makes you feel like your questions aren't valid. I would definitely take more of his classes.

Marshburn is a solid professor. He's clear, chill, and he knows his stuff. His lectures are not the most inspiring - they won't leave you thinking "damn that was brilliant", but he covers the material, gives many examples, and is very approachable. His exams are easy compared to the homework. Pay attention and understand the examples he does.

Awesome teacher.  Very clear in his lectures, and when I don't understand something, he's amazing at explaining difficult math concept one on one.  I recommend going to his office hours regularly even if you think you know the material because he'll make you know the material that much better for the exams
Marshburn is an above-average lecturer and an overall likeable teacher (fair grading, tests that cover familiar material, etc.) Wouldn't hesitate to take another one of his courses.
Comprehensive material. Lots of possibilities to contact him. Very useful homework. Very friendly. You have to study hard for exams, though.
Take calc II with ANYONE ELSE besides him. No further comments necessary.
Class is so hard and if you lack precision on tests you will fail. lectures are hard to follow and understand and a lot of times its right out of the textbok
Lots of proofs and less help on the actual problem solving front. However, he's a nice person, wants to help and see you succeed.
he's honestly not as bad as everyone says. You'll definitely have to teach yourself calculus but hey, its college so suck it up. pretty standard, no surprises. could be a lot worse.

The professor is an okay person. However, he's not clear at times. You have to be specific, but not VERY specific during office hours. At times, the confusing (though melodious) accent didn't help either.

He is a very very nice person and does encourage people to ask questions and is willing to help. Doesn't prepare people well enough for exams. Exams are fair. His lectures are almost useless when it comes to learning the material. He constantly makes mistakes on the board, and it causes a lot of confusing when trying to understand the work.
Open to questions. Office hours are useful.

He's honestly a pretty good professor. His accent might be a little bit difficult for people to understand, but it's easy to get used to. Calc II is a difficult course for many, but if you put in the effort, you should do fine. Jesus is always happy to answer questions, and when you do, he's quite helpful. Go to his office hours! He's also funny.
Literally worst professor i have had at johns hopkins. Did not show up to class for 2 weeks leading up to the exam.

In all my years of coursework I have never encountered a more inconsiderate or self-righteous instructor. He may spell his name J-e-s-u-s but he certainly did not die for humanity's sins, contrary to what his ego would have you believe. I am a firm believer in attending the lecture of courses, but his lectures only left me bewildered. Taught myself
Not a great professor. Most people stopped going to class because he was so unhelpful. Tough grading as well.

Okay, had such a horrible time in this class and learned nothing from it! THE CLASS IS SO BAD THAT I WANT THE TEACHER TO JUST RETIRE ALREADY. so many suffer all because the class is so badly organized. everything we do is so pointless. homework is dumb. worst class in the CS department

I know if I type "WORST CLASS EVER" then you won't take me seriously.  But seriously.  WORST CLASS EVER.  Sometimes that's all you can say.  But it's required for CS so all you can do is read this and be unhappy.
terrible lecturer, 80 problem homework assignments. lectures are worthless and exams are insane. do not take 600.333 with masson unless you have to!
taking it now. can't teach. don't inspire. waste of my summer money
possibly the worst class i've ever taken! this would be the kind of class you take absolutely because you have to. the prof absolutely can't teach.

Worst teacher I have ever had. Class is a waste of my time and the homework assignments are not related to class discussion at all. No grades matter but two tests which are impossible. Having to take this class made me hate Hopkins CS Dept. Test average was a 46, have fun guessing.
His classes are boring. Lectures arent much help either. Amount of attention kids are paying to him is miniscule
No Comments

My one big complaint about this class is that when you register, the course is marked as not being writing intensive. While technically true, there is EXTENSIVE reading which must be incorporated into weekly discussion posts, as well as two mid-term papers, and a 20 page final paper. Balance your classes well otherwise this one will drown you!
No Comments
This professor is intelligent,  but is not interested in teaching.  She will make the material much harder than it needs to be.
Professor takes pride in failing students and making them feel dumb. Economics is her life and it shows

Nancy is a working professional, so pay attention. Tips for success: 1) answer the DQs on time, 2) find hints in her lectures, 3) learn AP style, 4) read the grading rubric before writing an essay, 5) use your critical thinking in your analyses, and 6) focus on your group work. Grammar is important, so don't be lazy. She is one of my favorites!
He's brilliant and cares about his students  and classes. The subjects of his courses are fascinating. He is quiet and has a dry sense of humor that we all appreciate.

Professor McCarter is world renowned for his work on the dead sea scrolls.  He knows so much.  Sometimes his lectures are a bit hard to follow because of that.  But, he's interesting, helpful, and it all comes together in the end.

I had her for Intro to Archaeology.  I never really knew what to make of her personality, some days she seemed cold and intolerant, and others she was very nice.  The class assignments were generally graded pretty easy, but I had trouble with her midterm.  The final wasn't too bad.  Never really did the textbook, wasn't a problem for me.

I had her for Neanderthals to the Neolithic (130.102). She misplaces things, so make sure you email her too if you give her a hard copy of something. On midterms and finals, write your essays with the information she says in class. I found the textbooks unnecessary, but I was well-versed in the material before I entered the class.

Very interested in topic.  Multiple required books included one she wrote.  No class notes just stands and lectures so bring a laptop and get any days you missed from someone else.  If you do the work you will get a good grade.  Is very nice and will answer any questions you have.

Provides no feedback on hw/exams. Doen't participate in class discussions. Hw assignments are RIDICULOUSLY long. "Lectures" are simply textual summaries of the textbook. Group projects are pointless. Stats software is required, but he offers no instruction on use. I feel I was only able to do well in the course because I have a math degree.

Didn't participate in class. Expected to just read textbook and "get it", lectures were just textbook summaries. HW was 20 Qs, very time consuming and not helpful for deeper understanding. Offered minimal/unhelpful feedback ("this is incorrect" w/o any explanation). No expl of stat commands so good luck if u have no prior bg using the software.
Gives feedback in time

Professor McCarty speaks almost incomprehensibly soft, like he is speaking to himself. This makes it difficult to follow his material. His exam questions are very tricky. Worst professor out of the three General Biology professors. Learn all the names and equations you don't think you'll need to know.
Really laid back class. The material was difficult in the beginning, but gradually eased up to the point of being pointless. Easy to get a good grade if you put in the effort

really nice old prof; a bit absent minded sometimes; very lenient and is tenured so can do what he wants (field trips, take home exams). very fair, but teaches some hard material so that part is hard.

His powerpoints notes explain things really well. He really likes teaching, but its obvious that he's shy about talking in a 300 person classs. Out of the three lecturers in the class, he was the best. He was especially enthusisatic when teaching about plants since thats his research areas. His test questions were tricky but they were fair.

Dr. McCloskey is a true gem. His class structure provided a timeline to easily get all of the asynchronous work done and actually learn the material. He's a funny guy and his online lectures are easy to follow and very interesting. Taking his class confirmed that I want to study neuroscience because it's a really great intro to the field.

Dr. McCloskey is a true gem. His class structure provided a timeline to easily get all of the asynchronous work done and actually learn the material. He's a funny guy and his online lectures are easy to follow and very interesting. Taking his class confirmed that I want to study neuroscience because it's a really great intro to the field.

I had McCloskey for Visual Perception, which was the hardest class I've taken besides CogNeuro. His tests were difficult and not straightforward at all-even if you knew the material you could easily get confused by his questions and do poorly. Our grade was mostly based on these exams. He would also make inappropriate political jokes in class
Best professor ever

Dr. McCloskey is by far the best professor I ever had. The best thing about him is that he really has an incredible insight on the class materials he thought, and most of the time he was hesitant on agreeing with the case studies discussed in class. And that's a good thing cuz that's how science should be..too bad he taught only 2 classes here

Dr. McCloskey is an excellent teacher because he engages his students and encourages them to learn, instead of making them. He was my favorite teacher thus far because he made class interesting with case studies, made it funny with his humorous jokes, and made coming to class worthwhile. Because I wanted to learn, it became and honor to be in his c
very interesting class. I enjoyed it. There are lots of quizzes but it takes like 2minutes and really really really easy. However, the midterm and final is quite difficult and ambiguous.

The course was pre-designed with pre-recorded lectures. The guest lecture is very solid and Wooldridge's book was a good choice for textbook. Professor McCoskey pretty much played the role of a class facilitator grader. A's are hard for her class but B's are very doable as long as you are willing to read the book.

The course was pre-designed with pre-recorded lectures. The guest lecture is very solid and Wooldridge's book was a good choice for textbook. Professor McCoskey pretty much played the role of a class facilitator grader. A's are hard for her class but B's are very doable as long as you are willing to read the book.

The real issue with with this class was that she didn't proof read her assignments so there were material typos and ambiguities on every assignment that would effect the outcome of a regression. Second, her grading was arbitrary. She claimed to have a rubric but it clearly wasn't consistent. You'll pass but you can't count on her to be fair.

She now teaches Philosophy at Boston College and is honestly one of the best Philosophy teachers ever! Her lectures are so animated and logical(?). She is one of the few professors who understands that she is teaching a bunch of undergraduate students who don't know much about Philosophy. Her lectures are relatable and make sense.

She now teaches Philosophy at Boston College and is honestly one of the best Philosophy teachers ever! Her lectures are so animated and logical(?). She is one of the few professors who understands that she is teaching a bunch of undergraduate students who don't know much about Philosophy. Her lectures are relatable and make sense.

The most fun and engaging class I've been apart of so far. Class discussions are super engaging and she leads them expertly. She seems to really want to know what your opinions are and for you to be as informed as possible to make your own decisions. She has one of the best feminism related courses at massart.

Great professor. Smart as hell. You might just have a different outlook on life if you take her class seriously, she really takes you on a journey. Some subject matter is not easy for the narrow-minded to wrap their heads around. Lots of philosophy, lots of testing of theories.

Took her WritCom course at MassArt -- while it was nominally a class on essay writing, this was an advanced placement class and the bulk of the material was focused on philosophy and utilitarian ethics. Class was engaging and involved debate. She is very critical of your essays and doesn't just hand out As, but is fair and helpful. Good humored.

- Always interested in your questions   - Review sessions or at least gives you review notes so that you do well on the test.   - I took the class in a very small room and with few people, so I got tons of attention both inside and outside the class.

She is ery available outside the class and very interested in all of your questions, even the little and stupid ones. I def recommend any classes with her. She also has review sessions (at least she had when i was taking her class) and you go to the finals prepared.
She is a seriously awesome prof. I highly recommend any class with her. Her lectures are extremely organized and she's ALWAYS available outside of class for any help you might need.
She's clear, knows her stuff, and wants you to understand. Cool teacher.

Applied chem- The tests are hard as they are conceptual, include real-life problems. Still, tests have a small effect on total grade, the final is 14% vs hw is 20%. You really learn in this class and get a deep understanding. He really cares, and I really liked the course! Great curve too- B+ became an A. Great professor- tons of resources offered

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!The tests are so hard that the class average would always be around a 60 percent. He would not go over many topics bc he expects you to already know it from APChem(even though that material is not covered in APChem) Chemistry was my easiest subject in HS and I got a 5 on the AP exam take my word and dont take this class.

Applied chem- The tests are hard as they are conceptual, include real-life problems. Still, tests have a small effect on total grade, the final is 14% vs hw is 20%. You really learn in this class and get a deep understanding. He really cares, and I really liked the course! Great curve too- B+ became an A. Great professor- tons of resources offered
He's fine. The tests are definitely rough, but not impossible. Do well on the labs to get a high grade!

McQueen is approachable, but his lectures are too fast, like "this should be review from AP Chem" and skipped. The tests were kind of hard but inspirational and focus on application. Just don't be afraid and put down as much as you can. His gradings are super nice. The textbook is super helpful, even if you totally don't get the lectures.
Excellent professor. I learned a lot and would take another class by Prof. McQueen if I had the opportunity to .

Prof McQueen is a really nice dude. If you have any questions, McQueen will help you out. You can always email him for help - imo, one of the most available professors here. His exams are difficult but they're engaging and stimulating. If you just memorize content, you won't pass... You actually have to understand it. Lectures are great.
his exams are actual aids

Office hours were very very beneficial for me. Tests are very CONCEPTUAL, so learning how to do the mathematics and doing the homework is not enough to do well on exams. Office hours were helpful to learn things on the fundamental level and get rid of misconceptions. Very quirky man. Is willing to help students.. just dont be scared off by quirk.

McQueen is overall a really great guy and always willing to help his students. The tests are hard and dont really reflect lecture but the curve is very big which compensates for it. The lectures can go off on tangents but are engaging, and he always takes time to make sure you understand the material or answer questions if youre curious.

Professor McQueen is a wonderful educator, with generally fair exams and a reasonable amount of work. If you want to understand how things work on a fundamental level (and many things about poisons and explosions) then make sure to take his class!

I found Professor McQueen to be incredibly fair and clear in his explanations and lecture. Exams tough but fair and curve was generous. Does not deserve the low rating from people salty their grades. The point about not having answers in slides is valid, but there is a reason he said to print out lecture notes before class and follow along.

His exams are fairly difficult. His teaching style is fine, but the class itself is very messy - labs and lectures are almost never coordinated, so you need to stay on top of both separately in order to keep up. Given the difficulty of his exams, paying attention in class is not only necessary but also often not enough. Do the work and you'll be ok
Uses an active learning style and likes to give students practice problems in lecture. Prelectures before every class.

The tests are definitely much tougher than the homework. A lot of buffers are placed into one's grade to make sure it reflects effort rather than the two midterms one may have failed. Overall, for his first year, Tyrel is very responsive to feedback and makes the effort to improve his class. This man is a genius in the most stylish hawaiian shirts.
Please post solutions to the questions you have on your Powerpoint or at least write it down during class. Learning chemistry by listening to you go over answers doesn't help at all.

Tyrel Mcqueen is great! He is clearly very knowledgeable about chemistry  and his legendary Hawaiian shirts (most importantly the monogramed one) have helped me bond with people in my class more than any orientation activity. 10/10.

For his first time teaching a new class, he is doing a fine job. While I was at first blindsided by the formatting of the first test, and he made it difficult to understand what grade you had in the class, he has picked it up in the second half of semester and learned from his mistakes. He is quirky, but a good guy with a cool fashion sense.

This course is different from other classes in that the professor emphasizes on the development of skills that are important for the future instead of regurgitation of facts. It is definitely a course that takes up time, but if you are willing to stick with it, you get a lot out of it. The professor is helpful and wants everyone to succeed in class

It's a tough class; you'll need a solid knowledge of the basics in order to keep up with his higher level explanations, and he moves fast. He is very easy to talk to though, and always willing to re-explain something. Tests are very conceptual; long and hard but his curving is very fair. Put in the work, don't just memorize and you'll be fine.

He's a fine professor. Overly fair on problem sets (it's tough to get less than a 95 on each one), the grades are fairly distributed, and the tests aren't THAT bad. You're in college now, expect it to be more challenging
The hardest homework you will ever do.  The saddest glares you will ever see.
No Comments
No Comments
The hardest homework you will ever do.  Period.
It would be beneficial to write down every single thing she writes on the board. Usual weekly hw set, quiz, written hw due on the same day. Not a very good lecturer and exams are really hard
Good guy, genuinely likes the subject, is really good and somewhat easy over the summer. Summer class goes even slower than semester class.

Very thorough lectures and quite clear on what is expected on the tests. Some test questions come directly from book exercises. Meyer is pretty laid back as far as chemists go and his sarcastic humor is amusing at times. Great class overall.
Study previous exams
Meyer is uninterested in his students and hides this disinterest behind an "extreme" knowledge of Chemistry. No need to attend class and prepare to be confused.

Meyer was a good professor, but his tests were kinda hard. They weren't hard to do well on if you know your stuff. He doesn't recycle old questions as much cause some kids complained about that. Why, I don't know. But if you know the material, his exams are straightforward. Good lecturer too.

Meyer is a wonder professor and he is very nice. He covers everything that is relevant and is very clear about what will be on exams and what won't be on exams. He emails you back within a day and cares about the material he is teaching. I am so sad that I won't be able to have him next sem. Study the old exams cuz ALL the questions are recycled.

Definitely cynical and sarcastic during lectures. He'll pick on students who ask questions. But at the same time, extremely funny and entertaining. No textbook for this class. Lectures are useful but sometimes often Wikipedia supplement. Midterms come straight out of the HW packet. Class is easier than most ECE courses.
Taught half of the the semester but was a good professor. Jerry is the man.

Prof. Meyer is the most useless professor in the department (if he even shows up for class).  He is uniterested in his students and is extremely aloof!  He takes him home life out at work and all he seems to care about is running.

The most absolutely ridiculous professor at Hopkins. Would stand there after the ENTIRE class had failed an exam and lecture on how we had not taken the time to learn the material. I highly doubt that 300 people all didn't take the time to learn the material.

He was friendly and approachable. He definitely cares about whether his students learn the material. Some of the problems in this class stem from the TAs and the size of the class. Meyer ultimately doesn't grade the tests and figures out how the class is doing based on what the TAs say which is slightly problematic. He does try to fix any problems.
Covers all material clearly and effectively.  Overall, a great professor.
Most heinous prof ever. Very unsympathetic and unapproachable. Arrogant... I'd rather stick a pen in my eye than ever take his class again.
nice teacher, responsible
Make no mistake, Meyer hates you and everything you stand for.  He is entertaining and brilliant though and respects brilliance and little else.
great professor- take classes with him

AWESOME. Best chemistry professor at Hopkins. And he's a real human being- you can actually talk to him like a normal person (how many other professors are like that). One of the best professors overall, in fact...
Cynical and patronizing on any given day.  He has no respect for anyone or anything...especially microsoft and java.
Professor Meyer is a decent professor.  He is very very cynical (as mentioned before), he is also funny at times.  Tests are fair, and his lectures are clear.  He also hates M$, which is a plus.
No Comments
Great prof. best at hopkins. Very knowledgable and interested in the courses she teaches. much better in seminars than in lecture.

Prof. Meyer-Fong is a natural genius-- brilliant and clearly invested in her subject of interest. During discussions, she is enthusiastic about every student's comment, yet also doesn't let participants make useless comments for the sake of 'discussion points'. Her passion is contagious and makes attending class that much more absorbing.

Professor Micheli is an amazing educator and person. He loves his subject -- his passion is evident in lectures and office hours. He truly understands college students, and is very open to meeting and discussing strategies to improve. For his first time teaching the class online, it went quite smoothly!

Professor Micheli is an amazing educator and person. He loves his subject -- his passion is evident in lectures and office hours. He truly understands college students, and is very open to meeting and discussing strategies to improve. For his first time teaching the class online, it went quite smoothly!

The lectures are very clear and organized. Micheli emphasizes the full understanding of the theory. The homework and section worksheet problems helps to prepare for exams. The grade is curved, centering the average at like a B.
Very good professor! love him very much!Homework is very helpful, and all the problems provided are helpful

Professor Micheli is definitely one of the best Ive had at Hopkins. He manages to be entertaining and explain everything well and in-depth. Sometimes it may seem repetitive, but you can tell he wants you to succeed. Also, there are ample office hours available for extra help. This is a great class and professor for someone whos never take stats!

Great lecturer and very nice. His lecturers are very well organized and he goes at a good pace. He is very clear about what material is going to be tested, and tests are pretty straightforward. There is graded homework every week, but it isn't too much at all.

Super nice guy, lectures were super helpful (notes are posted online but not super timely so would not suggest skipping lecture) and we worked through the homework together during office hours. The only class at Hopkins where I think the effort you put in actually gets you the grade you deserve.
Nice mix of sample problems and theorems during lecture. The homework is harder than the tests (which I personally prefer) and all the problems on the homework are graded.
I wish he were still here!
Loved him!  Wished I still had him, since my English profs this fall are going to be squares.
Tony is the reason why I decided to be an English major.  Love him!
Totally challenging and well worth being challenged by.  Whoever said he's boring is probably bitter because he pushed them outside their comfort zone.
No Comments
He rocks
His class is very boring.

The Strategy Consulting Practicum was awful. He gave a couple lectures, didn't teach a single thing (we literally read the textbook in class), and the rest was just working with your respective client with null monitoring. Weekly HW (dumb assignments btw), ungraded until the end of the course. A real waste of money and time.

I took Prof. Milter for Leadership of Organization for my MBA and am a little shocked by all the negative reviews. Yes the class had a lot of assignments and projects, but 99% of it was rather simple, common sense things. Also, I liked the videos, lectures and journals as they helped me see way I could improve my leadership style in the real world
Heavy Group Projects Every  Week! A lot of work for an online course  The online sessions were not helpful to me!  It is very hard to contact the professor via emai or phone.
very tough Prof., class is very easy, but he made it hard. You should have to go under stress with this Prof.
Gave minimal effort. Students gave presentation every week. Most students felt that professor did not care about class. Avoid him if you can.
Gave minimal effort as teacher. Made you do lots of presentations, 8 to be exact. Terrible feedback. Most classmates felt he did not care about class. Avoid if you can.

Great instructor. Very out of the box thinker. Inspires students to be creative and innovating. Beware- very demanding syllabus and a lot of homework and presentations! Guest speakers also included, and very interesting. His course changed me.
Had Milter for Organizational Leadership - what a headache! Avoid!!

Really used blackboard, and there was a lot of homework, but the homework wasn't difficult.  I learned more in this class about Business Leadership than any that I have taken at JHU!  He invited lots of speakers which I found very interesting with real-world answers.  I would recommend this class to any future business leader

Four presentations in 10 weeks.. a lot of readings and teamwork, but he would give an A to all the teams. Individual assignments.. as long as you write something that could inspire him, you could at least get a B+. Lots of homework but he is not a hard grader. Always invite guests to join the class.

Gives great lectures. If anything he could be faulted for going too in-depth on certain topics, but it prepares you for later classes. Very good at explaining memory usage which is an important topic to know from this class. Also has clearest grading criteria I've ever seen. Every assignment comes with a point-by-point rubric.
There is a lot of reading and writing in Conversation Compostion but it really improves vocabulary, reading comprehension and writing ability. Speaking did not improve though.
Very nice professor. Gives a LOT of homework, but it does help you learn a lot of vocabulary.
Lot of material is covered. Need to stay diligent and understand the material. Very tough.
Not easy. Need to study a lot and make sure you understand the material. If you are behind, its its too late to play catch up. Good luck you will need it.

This is at UMGC! She never actually showed up to class. She is a glorified grader and didn't educate me at all. I wish I would have taken a different professor. Spending good money on my classes only to see that my professor grades my work is a huge let down. I had to open up a case about her 4 times because of different issues in the classroom.

I took his graduate seminar in Baroque Perfomance Practice, Beginning Viol, Viol consort, and baroque band and I have to say John is a very knowledgeable and very fun professor.  Class/rehearsal is never boring, and I have him (and his wife, Risa Browder) to thank for getting me going on baroque strings.  Plus, John wears the coolest socks ever.
What a great teacher! This professor makes me want to go to class. He facilitates discussions so we really learn!

Honors one-variable calculus was very challenging with him, but he inspires you to go onto further mathematical studies. The class was a little too difficult for a freshman-level math class because it incorporated elements from analysis and topology, but as an upper-level math professor he would be excellent.

i took jack for calc 1 when he taught at state univ. stony brook in the 70's. judging from the posts here, he is still the same texas jack. we called him jumpin jack flash. he had a trampoline in his office. to say we thought him eccentric is an understatement. but if you want to get inspired to do high level math...this is the guy to do it...

just scribbles on the board the entire class time. illegible handwriting. nice guy who knows his stuff, but can't teach. you're completely on your own to  learn from the textbook. had to switch to calc 1 to avoid him
awesomest prof ever!

Dude is a punk
 lectures are confusing and jump around to much
 
 tries to trip people on exams
While he is enthusiastic overall, he tends to get excited during lectures and speed up - a lot. Be prepared to befriend your book.
Nice guy. Great for talking outside class. Why the **** isn't he teaching Topology?
Lectures were very unclear and he seemed to enjoy tripping people up in the exams.
Harsh final, homework kinda time consuming, tough to follow in class so buy the book!!

Homework must be done, group sessions with fellow classmates can often lead to success, even on the night before.  To be honest, his tests ARE hard, but all that can be said is you MUST know by heart the things that he says are on them.
While people were getting killed by the final, he was doing  hand-stands at the front of the room. That's all I have to say...

Professor Morava is an intersting guy.  He seems nice, and his lectures were ususally clear (or as clear as a calcIII lecture can be), but unrelated to the work he assigned.  Also, his homework assignments and tests were pure crap.
He was a fun teacher and his exams were ridiculously easy
He flies thru lectures, leaving the understanding to be done at some other time. And he is a lunatic.
In Databases, Professor More taught the information very well. She clearly knew her stuff and cared a lot about her students and the fact that they learned.
In Databases, Professor More taught the information very well. She clearly knew her stuff and cared a lot about her students and the fact that they learned.

Professor More explained all of the concepts very well in class and the homeworks were very fair and tested us on all of the things a computer science class should test you on. My only gripe is with the exams in that handwriting code and obscure programming facts take center stage. Is handwriting code still a thing in interviews? I haven't seen it.

Sara is awesome!!! Mom energy, funny, accessible, never condescending. I found her CS220 lectures extremely clear, she is wonderful at answering questions. She guided me through my partner abandoning our team project, and believes in the potential of CS majors that arent Cool Coders Who Already Have Startups. A ray of sunshine in the CS Dept!

Overall, Professor Morgan was a pretty good professor. She was adept in facilitating conversation and in lecturing. Her grading fell somewhere between fair and harsh. The class was reading and writing intensive, though the professors did work to decrease the amount of writing between last year and this year. Overall positive experience

This class is great. Although the professor isn't always present in the discussions, the course is designed to be autotutorial. The textbook isn't really needed. There is quite a bit of writing here. There is a running group project throughout the course. This class requires work but it is not difficult. If you put the work in, you'll get an A.

He really loves his subject and it shows. He assigns too much reading for sure but you can get away with only reading about half/two thirds of it. He's a fair grader and the discussions were interesting. If you yourself are passionate about the subject I highly recommend you take him.
Moss is inspiring and very interested in what he is teaching, and class flies by. The grading system is super fair, but there is a decent amount of reading. My favorite class this semester!
Speaks waaaaaaaaaaaay too fast and gives you waaaaaaaay too much reading; and to think this is only an introductory course...

You can tell by the way he lectures that he's smart, used big words and foreign languages, but lectured like he was trying to defend a thesis than teach us European history. Was so abstract and jumpy that it was impossible to get anything out of his class. Required wayyy too much reading for an intro class. Didn't even have a textbook, really.
Knowledgeable professor, but better for upper level classes than intro. Kind of abstract and theoretical. Grading is fair.

Professor Moss is cute, but his lectures are so disorganized-- as are his reading assignments. Instead of a textbook there are over 10 books (as well as NUMEROUS accompanying articles) assigned.. costly, immensely time consuming, and hardly helpful. I HATE THIS CLASS
Good professor, not as tough as it seems
great teacher. took for living off the sun. great sense of teacher, very kind, very smart, goes slowly so everyone understands. great guy
He cares about his students - if you ever want to talk with him he'll talk with you, and explains stuff you need to know.

Took class spring 2008.  Awful teacher.  Lectures are unorganized and it's impossible to understand what he is saying.  If you somehow manage to understand what he's saying, exams are completely lecture based.  The textbook is worthless.
engaging conversationalist; passive

Very smart man. if your not interested in philosophy then you will find his lectures boring. He writes on the chalkboard alot, which i find helpful because philosophy is a process, and one that needs to be recorded so you can keep your place--and go back to ideas

horrible. horrible. probably the most boring person i have ever come across in my life. he doesn't talk to students while lecturing, he either talks to the blackboard or the floor. No eye contact. No smiling. Its horrible.

Moyar is kinda boring. His lectures are very detailed but his presentation is pretty dry. He tries to make jokes but nobody ever laughs. The readings were mildly entertaining. I had Plato, Descartes, Rousseau and Nietzsche. The grading was kinda opaque but I still got an A. Even if you bomb the papers you can always do a rewrite.
No Comments
His class was really hard but there was a big final grade curve. He made question banks to help us study for the final and was always available to talk. His handwriting could be a bit better, though.
His class was really hard but there was a big final grade curve. He made question banks to help us study for the final and was always available to talk. His handwriting could be a bit better, though.

WORST TEACHER EVER! disorganized lectures and unrecognizable handwriting. Midterms were completely different from lectures and hw. When I asked him for advice, he literally told me just to relax. Refused to give us rubrics for exams and told me we would all request for regrades and annoy him. Doesn't care about his students at all!
He's fantastic!

Definitely a great professor. She teaches you skills that will make you successful in future expos classes. You can tell she cares about her students and she always give great feedback. She also participates in faculty-student interactions.
Really great professor! Gives interesting readings and is really devoted to her students. I still visit with her even though I'm not in her class anymore.

Very friendly during lectures and made jokes often, but claimed class would be curved to a B+ and so he would indicate how many points you could add to your raw score to get your curved grade on exams, but in the end the class was not curved to a B+ and was curved lower. He curved down from what he originally stated as fact.
Makes it clear what will be on the test, pretty fair grading. Knows his stuff and makes funny remarks.
Good prof, awesome math jokes

Can you imagine my intro. to stats was taught by Prof. Naiman? I really like his way of teaching - writing in laptop touch board and projector to us in class. He asks questions on the proofs and derivatives during class which makes it a special experience. I build my confidence on stats from his 430.

Can you imagine my intro. to stats was taught by Prof. Naiman? I really like his way of teaching - writing in laptop touch board and projector to us in class. He asks questions on the proofs and derivatives during class which makes it a special experience. I build my confidence on stats from his 430.
He is the best instructor I ever had in all of my 15 courses. He is so cool. He spent a long time on the class. I never see a chairman hold office hours the whole afternoon like him.

I feel terrible about having to give him such bad ratings because he's such a nice guy, but his lectures are EXTREMELY hard to follow, which makes the tests very hard.  I would not recommend taking Stats II with him... wait for a semester when someone else is teaching it.
What a terrible teacher. He expects you to know wayy too much for the class and gives terrible quizzes that noone does well on. He says you don't need to know programming but you really do
No Comments
No Comments

Dr. Najmi's lectures are easy to understand. He gives feedback within a day at most when emailed with questions. Office hours are held via Zoom and are recorded, so you may go back a review at any time. This course definitely required the textbook as the lectures follow the book very closely. No exams or projects!

Dr. Najmi's lectures are easy to understand. He gives feedback within a day at most when emailed with questions. Office hours are held via Zoom and are recorded, so you may go back a review at any time. This course definitely required the textbook as the lectures follow the book very closely. No exams or projects!

70% of the grade is based on 3 group projects, the groups are assigned at random and there is no ability to be individually graded. If you happen to have a bad group the only options that exist is getting a worse grade than you probably could have alone, or to do the work for the entire team. I would not recommend this class at all.
I really enjoyed this class, the texts were interesting and Chris is awesome. Totally gay but really attractive in an older man way anyways. Loves what he does.
Ezpz lemon squeezy
Not the most exciting lectures. When I took the course, he made some comments about mental health that made me feel uncomfortable. I didn't ever feel excited to go to this class (intro to sociology).

So, this class's content is pretty much learned online with a physics program that is required for the ourse. I rarely paid attention in class, except to respond to mandatory questions that counted participation in the class. The professor is very nice, however, and usually reasonable.

Loved the class! Totally recommend for seniors. You learn more than you think, and Dr Nevin is really into the subject, since he was an army doctor. Hoping to score an A, but the final may be tough. Midterm was moderately tough, but very fair, just be sure to attend classes and do the readings.
Good seminar. Learned lots. Would recommend.

She's trying to put in so much in a single course with little guidance, and she has her own standards but won't let you know cause otherwise you'd figure out the right answers before submitting your assignments. It's ridiculous.

Policy Analysis is a core course required for the MPP program, however it doesn't do justice to the degree.
