She's a really nice and helpful teacher who actually cares about how you do in the class. You're lucky if you get her as your teacher

For an ISET course, it's rather lackluster. No 3D model building or VR for example. The final project is the only thing worth boasting about and that proved to be less valuable. As for Sack himself, I think Krieger should consider placing people where they're needed. I think he does VR/AR work, but he didn't fulfill the class description.
Mid term and Finals were especially brutal. The homework will take a good portion of time.
The class was the most hardest I ever took. Lot of homework and test and project but still I liked the class and the instructor
The class was the most hardest I ever took. Lot of homework and test and project but still I liked the class and the instructor

Dr. Safford is by far the worst teacher I have had in my entire 20 years of schooling. Her assessments are unclear, she is extremely unorganized, and she does not actually do any of the teaching. There are fabulous professors in this program, but Johns Hopkins needs to drop her.

Hardest class taken in JHU AAP by far. Course content was not difficult, but the work load was heavy.   Lots of reading, quizzes, and research. Exam weeks have quizzes for next unit  and project work due. Stickler for the rules, No Exceptions!  I would not recommend if taking other courses or working.

I took Principles of Immunology with Dr. Safford. The course is very information dense and we basically covered the entire text. At times it was difficult to manage all the assignments and homework with other classes. The assignments are intellectually challenging and fun to work on. Dr. Safford is extremely approachable both in and out of class.

Very low number of slides. Not specific, basically you have to memorize the whole book specially the figures. I honestly felt that I have to learn everything by myself. Every week you will have in average 4 assignments that takes a lot of time to do. Its not about what you learn but how good are you having "test skills", many tricky questions

I took principles of immunology with Dr. Safford in the AAP program and definitely recommend her.  She uses the Blackboard online component a lot (quizzes, discussion post) so you get a lot of points, but it can keep you busy.  She is very understanding when it comes to grading and gives you as many points as possible on tests.

She's awful. Her exams are ridiculously hard. She isn't understanding at all and she teaches with an attitude. She makes you basically memorize the entire book. She assigns way too much and expects too much and she does little on her end. Everything I've learned was self-taught from the book. She also grades extremely harshly.

Pros - lots of points to be had in assignments which all are worth more than the test. Cons - you will read and LEARN ON YOUR OWN (basically buying yourself a 4,000 USD "A"), short and diagram-based lectures, lots of busy work that tries to make you thinks, quizzes are so specific and they can be tricky and short-timed. Tip: find a smart group.

Dr Safford's class was one of the best I had during my MS program at Johns Hopkins. She knows her subject well and puts it across in a simple and understandable manner. Plus she gives extr credit assignments. Easy to score a good grade if you do your bit sincerely.
She is a pretty good. Professor. She may not explain everything very well in class, but she will take the time after the class to make sure you know the subject matter.
She doesn't explain things well and cannot conduct a lecture whatsoever.  Also does not use assigned texts for easy reference.  Too much busy work.  Not very experienced in handling class situations
Hard class but was worth it. Learnt a lot, especially how to use models to simplify and solve economic problems.
Did not know what to expect for the exams. Dont take a class with him if you love your GPA.
Very helpful and a great instructor!

I took DiffEq and Calc II w him. Most def my favorite professor at Hopkins!! N by far the best Math prof in this school! He is absolutely AWESOME! He is a really good teacher and you know what to expect for exams. He's a really cool guy too and his personality comes through in his teaching. If you can take any of your courses with him -- do it! =)
awesome

Salch is a really special person. He is in academia not to accumulate awards or accrue status, nor because he likes punishing unsuspecting undergraduates. He does math research because he enjoys solving problems. This kind of person is far too rare these days in higher ed. I suspect he will do great things in mathematics.  -N.O.

This guy is hilarious!!! He always seems really friendly and is good about answering questions. He really seemed like he wanted everyone to learn the material. Probably one of my favorite professors that semester.

Solid teacher. He can connect with the kids because he kinda is one. Has big gauges in his ears and is tatted up from head to toe but hes the man. Fun and easy class if you do all the work which is not much.
Amazing. So so so nice and helpful! He is really easy too, so don't hesitate to join his class :)

What a wonderful professor. He always stopped to answer EVERY question in a huge lecture, and explained things well and often. Always stayed after class to answer more questions. Very nice and I never fell asleep in his class because he kept things moving, and his voice wasnt monotonous. he was great, esp. for his 1st yr at jhu.
I love her

Took Contemporary French II as well as Franco-Caribbean Lit with her as professor. Extremely intelligent and organized, she created a really sophisticated syllabus and engaged students in very thoughtful & challenging discussions that truly inspired interest in the material. She's at Duke now, but will be missed at Johns Hopkins!

Took French Cinema with her and it was absolutely amazing. The class content was fascinating; I think I learned more in that class about film and history than in any other class, and my French improved a lot as well. She's also genuinely interested in her students, and is a very fair grader. And she's gorgeous, with impeccable style.
No Comments
She can be tough grader but it's worth it. Learning Spanish is tough.

Loreto is HILARIOUS. She's so warm and friendly and makes class enjoyable. That being said, she conducts class 100% in Spanish and speaks 1000/mph so be prepared for that! She also calls on you at random but as long as you do the homework for every class it's not a big deal at all. She really cares and wants her students to improve thei
Worst ever!
Very helpful and tries to be as clear as possible, but class is very hard. Exams and homeworks are fair and very useful in understanding the material.
Really great guy, a lot more tame than his counterpart mark in writing for the law

So, yes, this class is entertaining and Sandhaus is a funny guy. However, his exams are absurd, which made me dislike him very much by the end. His lectures aren't based on an in-depth reading of the textbook, but the exams ask ridiculously specific questions from the text. Almost no point in taking notes in lecture. Just read, meticulously
teacher is so good looking omg

Great professor - very entertaining and humorous and has a lot of valuable experiences to share with class that he often likes to talk about. Occasionally plays educational-pranks/jokes on the class which are funny as well. Definitely recommend. Grading is done by TA but at least my TA was fair generally.
Is there a reason why he teaches here and not in a law school???  Hmmmm...
Extremely fun to listen to. Very exciting speaker! Somewhat difficult exams. If you go to lecture and listen carefully (and read the textbook) you'll get a good grade.
awesome class
Hilarious. Take the class.
This guy is hilarious, take his class.

It is quite funny to listen to this guy. He doesn't take himself seriously and loves to tell stories about himself. The class is easy if you attend the weekly lectures.
 
 In conclusion, everyone should take this class.
No Comments
Take this class. That is all.

Honestly a joy to have! Very understanding and reasonable. Ever so slightly disorganized at times, but nothing realistically painful. Most of all, there for her students and their experiences, not just their grades.

Honestly a joy to have! Very understanding and reasonable. Ever so slightly disorganized at times, but nothing realistically painful. Most of all, there for her students and their experiences, not just their grades.
She is a great teacher, her material is clear cut. The homework took a long time but its because it was a design course. She was very helpful when I went to office hours.
She is pretty useless during lecture. Does a lot of proofs that are almost impossible to follow and do not matter. Just remember the equation at the end of it and do the homeworks.

There's a pretty uniform consensus in our classes that she doesn't know how to teach, she fumbles variables and makes countless errors on the board and expresses a condescending attitude when people point out her lack of teaching skill. Read the book during class, what she writes on the board is circular and convoluted.
very nice professor, always willing to help outside of class.  tests and grading were fair; make sure you read the book.  overall a great class.

Very helpful if you see her after class, lectures can be confusing though. Be sure to read the book beforehand, or else you will be lost. Like I said though, be sure to develop a one-on-one connection with her, she's very receptive to extra help.
Lectures are not at all helpful. You're better off reading the textbook and learning it yourself.
Very kind and very helpful. Really liked her.

Although at the beginning of the class, she made many mistakes or did an example she did not want to show. It confused the heck out of me. As the class progressed though, she relatively got better. Lectures acted as good review. REcommend reading the book before lecture.

She simply didn't prepare for lectures.  She came in and tried to re derive stuff without proper notes and failed miserably, often staring at the board for long intervals trying to figure out what went wrong.  by a friends tally, less than 1/3 of the class still attended at the end of the semester.

WORST PROFESSOR. dont even bother attending the class - you can't really understand her and her notes are only average and contain mistakes. you're best off just reading and learning from the textbook

Professor is really kind, but the helpfulness of the lecture is questionable. As far as I know, most of students in this class studied the text book for the final prep. The lecture note is hardly in use.
"Lectures don't help"

He overcomplicates everything. Going to lecture actually confused me more than just skipping lecture, looking at the homework, and teaching myself. Test questions were different in style to those in the book and the professor never really worked out the problems in class, just theory, which fed into the overcomplication.

Savitt is the worst teacher I've ever had. Class is theory based (aren't we trying to learn math?), homework is unrelated to lectures, and test questions barely have to do with either. If you took AP Calc in high school you should be fine (may even want to skip lecture so you don't have to listen to his annoyingness) but otherwise you're screwed.
He's pretty okay.

Condescending to adult learners, demonstrated significant technical challenges with online course platform causing students to access exams and modules late, slow to respond / provided insufficient responses to student emails, and focused more on arbitrary formatting details on essays than demonstration of correct physiology concepts.

This is the first time I've ever rated a professor. I'm here to say... Do not take Professor Sazama's class. She'll essentially dock you every point she can on a rubric just to remind you that you are a student, not a professional. Reach out for feedback and she'll simply remind you that you have a lot to learn but she wishes you the best of luck.
Grading criteria not clear, technical difficulties with course and did not respond in timely manner. Arrogant in responses.
good

I had the pleasure of taking Ed Scheinerman's first online class, and he was such a good professor that I'm rating him before getting my final grade. He is flexible, available, and very understanding. If you are struggling, with your schedule or the content, don't hesitate to email him. He is honestly one of the best professors I have had.
He's cool and very nice!
No Comments

I really enjoyed Professor Schiavone and learned so much. I like her advice for an eye catching powerpoint. If you have never written a white paper, you'll learn how to. You'll get great feedback on papers. I wish she gave better guidance on how to prep for the final exam and what your score is on that test. Otherwise, I like her teaching style.
Avoid taking her class if possible. She just loves to talk. Always be ready to be called out and say what you think. The most stressful class ever.

I really enjoyed Professor Schiavone and learned so much. I like her advice for an eye catching powerpoint. If you have never written a white paper, you'll learn how to. You'll get great feedback on papers. I wish she gave better guidance on how to prep for the final exam and what your score is on that test. Otherwise, I like her teaching style.

She is a horrible professor. She is not professional and she discussed non-class related stuff and wasting my time. Don't take her class. Also, she will give you a hard time for no reason. Her exams are based on readings but she will not discuss readings at all to prepare for the exam. Don't know why she is qualified to teach at all at Hopkins.

Her lecture is super random and not so much related to the course materials. We have to buy textbooks while she didn't cover any readings. Her power points are not well designed either (ironically she teaches how to design the ppt)...

Avoid this class if possible. Professor has a lot of experience but she needs to organize the materials better. Assignment requirements are not clear. Readings are not discussed in class. She also needs to improve use of technology.
Great feedback and tips, lectures are hilarious and she incorporates her experience and brings awesome speakers.

Took the class as a requirement, but the class is quite useless for a graduate level class. Most of the time you will discuss news, with quite a subjective and one sided opinion from professor. Try not to contradict to what she says it will not end well for you!

The most unprofessional lecturer I've ever met. Do not post grade of every assignmentpresentationpaper in the student system and just generally say you guys did a good job and then give you a B for this class. 34 of the time you listen to her boring story. If you got choices, try others.
Professor Schiavone was really helpful and willing to do whatever she could to ensure that students got as much as possible out of the class. I learned a lot from her class.

It is silly that this instructor teaches at a business school. The professor is a journalist with no understanding of business. Her critiques of student papers/presentations were rarely logical or well thought out. However, she is a very nice person with good stories to share.
Grade based on several writing assignments and class presentation. Final exam was very easy and based on minimal reading. Does not allow computers in class.
tough

He was the worst professor I've had at Hopkins. Failed to update material for an online course. The grades section had different due dates than the individual modules, and the syllabus. He barely responded to emails, and didn't respond to most Discussion board Q&A. ZERO feedback so you could improve between assignments. AVOID AT ALL COST!! HORRIBLE
Fair grader
subjective grader, not flexible
No clear grading criteria, very subjective
Didn't provide evaluation rubric
Clear and supportive.
A lot of work but very fair.  The class involves a lot of cases which are both interesting and fun.
Clear
Great guy! Very fair with grading. Knows the subject very well!
Be prepared to do all the work yourself
His exams include stuff not covered in class. Does not return assignments on time. Duplicitous and inflexible
Moves fast, but is really clear and concise in her explanations. Everything is clear if you do the reading. Seems enthusiastic, energetic, and interested in subject.
Pros: fair exam questions, receptive to student's questions, colored chalk!    Cons: lectures seem disorganized, doesn't always answer student's questions clearly.
This rating has been removed as per our site guidelines.
defensive if you contradicted her, doesn't relate to students, unorganized, moved WAY too quickly... ugh!

An absolutely fantastic lecturer.  Her lectures are very fast-paced, but you'll be able to keep up if you do the reading, and the pace of the lectures and quality of the material make class stimulating and exciting.
She was a fantastic teacher, very approachable outside to class,
No Comments
ugh, snippy and unhelpful, can't relate to students
Very disorganized, gets defensive, lectures too fast

Dr Schwartz is a great teacher and is always willing to help you understand the topic/material.  I took this class freshman year and to this day, Dr Schwartz still remembers my name and says hello to me in the halls.

A great prof...fair exams..generally nice and approachable, tries to get students involved in the discussion, passionate about the subject..only downside is that you get a final exam and a final paper.
Easy-to-understand, interesting lectures. A lot of reading, but not hard. Tests not difficult--very similar to practice exams.

The class is awesome and he's really into his subject. He's easy to understand and makes it clear what's expected of you. Never try to answer his in-class questions: you will always be wrong. Only Schwartz can have the correct answer!

Attendance isnt mandatory, but if you attend class regularly and do the reading, you should be well set for the exams. Sometimes he can be mean and unhelpful (he hates undergrads), but the course is really interesting if you want an introduction to Near Eastern Studies.
Good lecturer, he seems genuinely interested in what he is talking about. Very knowledgeable.
very enthusiastic
Seemed annoyed at having to teach the class.

I thoroughly enjoyed taking Advanced Cell Bio2 with Dr. Schwartz. The class heavily revolved around the application of the course material which made the class less rigid. Dr. Schwartz is a very personable and direct professor that tends to her students with prompt responses. My best advice would be to focus on the midterm as the final was fair.

I thoroughly enjoyed taking Advanced Cell Bio2 with Dr. Schwartz. The class heavily revolved around the application of the course material which made the class less rigid. Dr. Schwartz is a very personable and direct professor that tends to her students with prompt responses. My best advice would be to focus on the midterm as the final was fair.

Dr. Schwartz is a great professor. She provided the class with annotated lectures in ppt format, many of them were with audio comments. She participated in the discussions, submitted grades usually within a week and replied every email within the same day or the next day. This course takes effort.
Excellent Professor. The disease presentation assignment links theoretical biochemical knowledge to a practical application. I love it.

I really enjoy it!  Able to learn and grasp the molecular biology techniques and their practical application. Based on the experience with research project, I can leverage it for similar research study in the future courses.

Dr. Schwartz taught me not only the knowledge in cell biology, but also the way of thinking. I think this is the most important thing. Knowledge changes all the time, it is significant to know how to learn.

Dr. Schwartz has excellent online course. The weekly workload was well set up, with a reading, lecture, wiki, and discussion. Enough to really learn the material without being overwhelming. The content and design of the course had an excellent blend of textbook, research, writing, and student engagement that resulted in anyone who tried learning th

Dr. Schwartz was the Best professor I ever had. The instructor is very knowledgeable about the course material. She is in fact an expert in the field and one can tell by how invested she is about providing up to date information for the class. Dr. Schwartz helped us understand the applications of what we were learning and even gave us the confidenc

Dr. Schwartz is literally the worst professor I've ever had. I have a very strong background in biochem and I feel as though I've lost it because of her. Her lectures are not representative of what she is expecting on the exams and she allows the class to get derailed for 40 minutes or more at a time. She should not be teaching.

Dr. Schwartz is difficult to comprehend during class. She states random facts about biochemistry that are blatantly wrong. She doesn't post the lectures, tests, etc on time. However, she does have a lot of information on the biotech industry, but I feel like she does not have time to teach this class and should focus on her other careers.

I really cannot understand why a good name school, like Johns Hopkins, hires such an incompetent instructor. I already had PhD from another university before I started MS at the Applied Economics program, and I have seen all kinds of instructors, but I rate him the worst I have had since grade school. He cannot even answer basic questions.

Amazing professor. Dr. Selbie responds very quickly to any emails and provides a ton of valuable feedback in case students needs any help. A lot of research articles to read, leading to weekly discussions. A couple of group projects and few quizzes with a final exam. I would highly recommend taking her class if you want to learn Cell Bio.

Amazing professor. Dr. Selbie responds very quickly to any emails and provides a ton of valuable feedback in case students needs any help. A lot of research articles to read, leading to weekly discussions. A couple of group projects and few quizzes with a final exam. I would highly recommend taking her class if you want to learn Cell Bio.

Makes you work for it! Wants perfect answers after a lot of reading and research. But if you've put in the effort, the exams can be cracked. Perfectionist. But this course makes sure that you learn a lot!
Would recommend taking this teacher for Cell Biology at Hopkins. Was good class

Dr Selbie was an excellent teacher who stressed critical reasoning skills and problem solving, rather than rote memorization and regurgitation. All the tests where open-book, gave partial credit on the multiple choice, and was very fair in the grading. Yes there is lots of reading, projects & quizzes/tests, but if you want to learn Biology take her

This class is based heavily on weekly discussions and group projects. The midterm and final are take home, essay based exams. There is quite a bit of work required in this class. Memorization is required but using the textbook for quizzes and exams are crucial. This class also focuses a lot on experiments. An A is possible but needs a lot work.

Dr. Selbie is very personable 1:1. That approachability sort of stops in class though. The group projects are pointless papers and there is no accountability. The lectures are dense and boring. The book graphics are designed by amateurs. I struggled through this class because it was so uninspiring, and classically dull.

Probably the best professor I have ever had! Took Stem Cell and Advanced Cell Biology with Selbie - very good problem solving assignments, good overviews of material (rather than worthless memorization) and group assignments help you learn the material. I would recommend her for the JHU Biotechnology program!

Don't take this class if you value your sanity. She doesn't respond to any messages and when she does arrange for an actual meeting, she fails to show up. She says she doesn't want stuff done in a cookie-cutter approach, but that just means she doesn't want to give us a rubric to go off of. There is no direction with this class with projects/tests.
She knows what she's talking about and is passionate about CS, but she is a little bit nit-picky about things like code style.

When you ask her a question she seems very eager to finish answering your question so that she can move onto other more important things, even if it means that she doesn't do a good job answering the question. Often her answers and extremely brief, vague, and not helpful. She makes many mistakes during lecture which makes the class hard to follow.

I took this class over the summer and it was one of most useful classes. Although I am not a JHU student, I found this class to be very interesting and helpful in understanding programing. It is a tough class when taken in summer, but it's rewarding.

I found that often the professor was not as familiar with the material as she should be. She also does a horrible job at explaining concepts to the class. She teaches her intro classes at a much harder level then it should be.
She is a very good professor. I really learned a lot from her.
Has great perspectives on life, universe, and everything be sure to ask questions either in or out of class if you want to make the most of your time studying under this man.

Dr. Shelby is an amazing professor. His lectures are clear and thorough. He genuinely cares for his students and takes from his personal time during weekends to support them. The grading is fair, and the discussions are very insightful. I would recommend taking a class with Dr. Shelby any day. He is a wonderful, wonderful person.

Dr. Shelby is an amazing professor. His lectures are clear and thorough. He genuinely cares for his students and takes from his personal time during weekends to support them. The grading is fair, and the discussions are very insightful. I would recommend taking a class with Dr. Shelby any day. He is a wonderful, wonderful person.
Word of advice: talk to her and not the TAs. She's incredibly generous and willing to sit down with you and go over your outline/paper. Best prof at Hopkins!

Melanie Shell-Weiss is the best professor at Johns Hopkins!!!!! She is really invested in her sudents. Knowledgable, caring... I have taken a lot of history classes, but she is really amazing. Every professor should be like her.
Very knowledgeable, extremely effective teaching, and always there for assistance.
He's really not that bad. His class is pretty easy, and its interesting as well. I don't know why people thought he was unclear. I found him, his lectures, and assignments to be perfectly clear.
His occ civ class is really not that hard and it's required for IR majors

Very weird guy, very confusing/incomprehensible lectures, but the class is not very hard at all and you have to take it if you're an IR major. Let me put it this way, I did very little work and occassionaly skipped lectures and I still got an A in the class.
One of the worst professor's I've ever come into contact with. His lecture's were incoherent and the course was disorganized as a whole.

His lectures were very unfocused and had nothing to do with the readings. However, I do think that I learned a lot about analyzing historical event, despite the fact that he didn't really teach them. He assumed way too much of the knowledge of the students' of European history.
No Comments

In intro to machine learning, you will implement machine learning algorithms from scratch, write complex papers, and submit a video for every assignment. Grading requirements are vague. Requirements for submission, format, etc. are over 20 pages long. I spent more time on this class than my full time job.

Dr. Shilliam is a true gem! Not only are his classes inspirational and a transformative learning experience but he is also highly cognizant of students' feedback, expectations from him and the course, and how to help each person individually. Also one of the most perceptive and intelligent instructors that I have ever had! So happy I took him

Dr. Shilliam is a true gem! Not only are his classes inspirational and a transformative learning experience but he is also highly cognizant of students' feedback, expectations from him and the course, and how to help each person individually. Also one of the most perceptive and intelligent instructors that I have ever had! So happy I took him
Hands down one of the best professors I've had. Very informed, open to questions, and funny. His lectures are always helpful and provide great examples.
Hands down one of the best professors I've had. Very informed, open to questions, and funny. His lectures are always helpful and provide great examples.

Lectures are relatively boring, not very lenient with points. In my personal experience, not very approachable (I always spoke to Pearlman instead). Posts lectures online but use the Panopto recordings since he mentions some things that are not included on the slides.

Shingles is one of the worst professors I've ever had. In my experience his lectures were incredibly boring and difficult to understand. He only cares about the postbac students, not the undergraduates. He will not give points back, even after telling you your answer was correct. Avoid at all possible costs.
Mumbles and does not give enough time for the clickers. Easy A, despite vague and ambiguous test questions/answers.
Don't buy the textbook or Launchpad- never used either, got A
Amazing PowerPoints and lectures. Interactive lectures help zero in on the details, which are very important for tests.

Best PowerPoints out of General Biology 1 lecturers. Very clear lectures with examples. Look at past exam questions. Pay attention to details, they will be on the exam. Good lecturer, just make sure you go back and review material - there's a lot you need to know (use past exams as a guideline).
No Comments

His lectures were succinct, coherent, and clear. He does an excellent job of throwing in interesting examples and applications beyond the text. Answers emails quickly and is helpful during office hours. The material of general biology is relatively straightforward, be sure to split up your studying into smaller pieces b/c there is a lot to know.

Prof Shore is a very enthusiastic Econ professor, perhaps my favorite econ professor at JHU. His class is hard if one does not pay attention in class and take good notes. The textbook is not too useful/necessary. His exams were hard, but he gave a decent curve, meaning that if you knew about 80% of the material, you'd get an A.
I had him for microtheory and although the class was terribly difficult he was the best teacher I have had at Hopkins hands down.
The class is hard but Professor Shore is the greatest econ professor I've ever had. No joke, awesome. People failed his midterm, but they probably didn't study much. It's Hopkins, it's hard.
Easy class if you have any ability to do math. The professor may go through topics very quickly, but he makes the material very basic to understand.
Doesn't teach the information well and is notorious for giving one of the hardest tests at Hopkins.  His class makes people switch majors.
I had Shore for Micro Theory, and it was the hardest class I've ever taken. He tried to teach, but he was too arrogant.
Awesome professor but hard class.

Took Shuster for Cinema and Philosophy. We watched movies and read philosophy, what more can you ask for in a class? Shuster is very funny and definitely got me to think about things in a new way. He expects a lot from you, though--a paper and a final project, but he grades reasonabely.

Martin is simply the greatest professor I've ever had, really.  He's *extremely* clear and to the point, insightful, and a subtle reader of complicated texts.  I highly suggest taking courses with Martin.

Great class!  Never taken anything quite like it...has sort of strange final project, but class overall is fantastic...good lectures, great readings.  Seems to take an interest in his students, would take again.
Great lectures, funny, but sometimes too philosophical
Great prof, funny.
Other rating is way excessive. But Martin's good and very relaxed.
No Comments
The class was bit heavy on assignments. But the lectures were amazing, with lots of scope for in-class thinking, participation, discussions etc.

Great professor, very knowledgeable about the subject and makes many connections to outside references. Felt like I was learning a lot about history and life in general instead of just the texts that were assigned. However, he is not an easy grader.
Inspiring--passionate about his subject.  Hard but fair.

Monica was a wonderful teacher truly interested in the subject she teaches and earnestly concerned that students learn their material. She was great at latin and, though softspoken, made sure that everyone participated and learned. Excellent class and teacher

She is very kind and obviously enjoys what she does. I was in her intermediate latin class and overall, it was very easy to do well. She seems genuinely concerned if the students are learning. She can be a little soft spoken at times, but that's not always a bad thing! Great Teacher!

Took his Religion + Culture course at Brown. Absolutely loved it-> the course is made up of readings with a takehome midterm + final. There is a LOT of reading! But always interesting and engaging, although it might be very hard to understand in the beginnin.g Bhrigu is also engaging when lecturing and discussing, and is clear in explanations.

Took his Religion + Culture course at Brown. Absolutely loved it-> the course is made up of readings with a takehome midterm + final. There is a LOT of reading! But always interesting and engaging, although it might be very hard to understand in the beginnin.g Bhrigu is also engaging when lecturing and discussing, and is clear in explanations.

Hands down, the best teacher I've had at Hopkins.  The two classes I took were rich with readings from all ends of the spectrum, and for once I actually felt motivated to participate in discussions and explore beyond the required busywork.  I could not recommend him more highly.

Bhrigu in an outstanding professor who inspires interest in his field and beyond. He is extremely fair and will offer multiple opportunities to succeed. He was receptive to emails and was available for help outside the class. I found the class to be difficult at times, but it was probably because he had us thinking so much and so creatively!

Bhrigu is fantastic. He knows his stuff and goes to great pains to explain it. Best class I took at Hopkins. He is brilliant and a really great guy. I didn't know I could like or understand Philosophy until I took this class. But Bhrigu really drew me in and blew me away.

Bhrigu was one of the worst professors I have encountered at Hopkins. Led me on the entire semester to believe I had a much higher grade, then blasted me when it came time for finals. Very unfortunate. Horrible teacher with little compassion. Seems to operate in his own world with all other opinions simply dismissed.

His class is fun and easy to follow with lots of great personal stories for leadership theories. You can do really well on weekly papers if you write specific examples. I used textbook but it's not mandatory.

His class is fun and easy to follow with lots of great personal stories for leadership theories. You can do really well on weekly papers if you write specific examples. I used textbook but it's not mandatory.
Not really any good.

Dr. Smith is a nice person, but her lectures are very frustrating to try to follow. The material isn't that hard, but half the difficulty of the class has come from the sheer work of deciphering the convoluted, redundant recorded lectures. Discussion sections are very, very superficial, but the exams require much more knowledge. Avoid this class.

Brian is one of the best professors in the math department. While calculus may be difficult at a college level, Brian is the best prof to have for this class. His lectures are clear as long as you stay engaged and take good notes. Confusing topics can be learned outside of class using the textbook.

Had a horrible experience with Dr. Smithling. He sure knows his math, but I believe that's also his downfall. He explains content quickly and in ways that expect you to already have the majority of the content down prior to coming to class. He is not very caring and will in fact increase the workload when you're at your worst. No accent though!

Brian is one of the best professors in the math department. While calculus may be difficult at a college level, Brian is the best prof to have for this class. His lectures are clear as long as you stay engaged and take good notes. Confusing topics can be learned outside of class using the textbook.

Brian is an extremely difficult professor. His lectures do get easier to understand as the semester goes on, but his exams are always extremely hard. If you are not good at math, I would not recommend taking his class because you will most likely struggle terribly. If you easily understand math concepts, this class is for you.

Brian's a great professor and super easy to talk to. His lectures are overwhelming at FIRST but he explains complicated things in very easy to understand ways. The backtests he provides are extremely useful and his exams are fair. The exam averages for his class are low but THERE'S A HUGE CURVE (if you average a low B, you'll get an A).

While initially "Brian" made Calc1 seem very confusing with his use of math jargon and symbols. It becomes easier to get used to them and see that he has very well planned and organized lectures laid out. He without a doubt knows the topic like the back of his hand and is easy to talk to outside of class. Somewhat hard class but not impossible.

Brian was an engaging and energetic professor. However, I will say that it is very necessary to read out of the textbook and make sure you understand the homework problems. He provides plenty of backtests that were very helpful if you complete before exams. You have to study if you want to pass, but overall, it was a rewarding experience for me.

Initially, I loved Brian. He's an energetic and engaging lecturer. However, his class (Calc I) was a disappointment every other level. The HW problems were questionably chosen, the TA was awful, and Brian missed multiple lectures which had ABYSMAL substitutes. Tack on poorly designed exams and the class has become my least favorite ever.

Brian (we call him Brian) is AWESOME. He's sarcastic and encouraging and, best of all, actively disavows math that he doesn't think we need to know. In his words, "I hate partial fractions, so there's no way I'm going to make you do them." It's not an easy class, but it's one in which you want to go to each and every lecture just to hear Brian!

He is a kind guy who is very intelligent and approachable outside of class, but Sogge is a mediocre lecturer at best. He is subpar at explaining things and the handwriting on his slides is awful. Grading is fair, but if you don't have a calc background you might struggle. If you have taken AP/IB calc you should do well if you do HW consistently.

He's a great guy, not the best lecturer. Tests are very difficult; 2 midterms and the final make up the vast majority of your grade. Practice problems beyond just homework is essential for success. Final was very difficult, usual concepts but makes you apply them in ways not specifically covered in the course.
Kind but not the best teacher

I had Dr. Sorenson for PEBL and she is my favorite professor so far! PEBL was wonderful, and I learned so much new material even though I had no background in biochemistry. Dr. Sorenson is very helpful during office hours and during the pre-lab lecture. Course load is demanding, but doable if you put in the work. Would definitely recommend!

Dr. Spall is one of the most strict professor from AMS department, but, you will learn a lot from his class. He put lots of time prepare his class, lecture notes, and literatures. You will struggle in his class, overwhelmed with homeworks and quizz and exams, but you will learn a ton after the class.

Dr. Spall is one of the most strict professor from AMS department, but, you will learn a lot from his class. He put lots of time prepare his class, lecture notes, and literatures. You will struggle in his class, overwhelmed with homeworks and quizz and exams, but you will learn a ton after the class.

Clearly knows his subject material. Grading can be a little tough (he tends to be nitpicky about careful writing and notation). Exams are generally fair but somewhat time-consuming, so need to work efficiently or risk not finishing. Hard grader who doesn't tend to give much partial credit.

Professor Spall was one of the best professors I had at Hopkins. However, his courses are very tough. Do not expect any of his courses to be walk in the park. In fact, expect them to be far more difficult than the average course. That being said, his courses are very rewarding. I wish I had taken every one of his courses while at Hopkins.

Dr. Specter was great and very accessible, I'm a math major in the department and he has been one of my favorite profs to work with. Linear Algebra can be a difficult subject to grasp at first but if you reach out to him or go to office hours he's very helpful. His lectures were well taught and always amusing.

Dr. Specter was great and very accessible, I'm a math major in the department and he has been one of my favorite profs to work with. Linear Algebra can be a difficult subject to grasp at first but if you reach out to him or go to office hours he's very helpful. His lectures were well taught and always amusing.
Easy A in his class
Easy A in his class

Great professor. She moves fast but she's extremely clear and makes even the dullest material interesting and engaging. Be prepared to take a lot of notes and pay strict attention, but also expect to get a lot out of the class. I had no interest in medieval history before The Medieval World and now it's one of my favorite courses.
very passionate, enthusiastic and clear. Her class The Medieval World is great.
Totally forgettable prof. Heavy accent on top.
He's an absolutely fantastic professor. Explains concepts very clearly and makes reading the book unnecessary. He genuinely wants his students to do well...plus, he's absolutely ADORABLE.
He is a great professor and explains Calc. III really well. Very good at drawing on the blackboard so that you can visualize the concepts. BTW, he had a silver medal in World Olympiad in Math.

Spinu is THE MAN! His lecutures were so bizarre (the  man compares functions to sushi--plus, you've gotta love the Romanian accent and how he bumps in to random objects every few minutes....) and interesting that I would recommend attending every single one. Tests are hard, but he wants you to succeed and drills a few concepts.Good prep for calc 2.

Florin Spinu is an awesome professor. It'ss hard to understand him, but if you do the weekly homework and go to lecture somtimes, you should be able to do fine. Also, you'll want to go to lecture just to hear some of the funny things he says. "Where do you find the limit? Do you find it at a grocery store?"

funny guy but he does get frustrated when the class doesn't get something. hard class, but he tries to make you see math from a different angle by trying to make you forget the formulas and stuff you learned and teaching you to figure stuff out from scratch

Spinu is very intelligent (Harvard, Princeton grad). His English isn't great, but it's amusing sometimes to watch him misspell words like "number" (ironically). He is pretty thorough and tries to get the class involved. But he does try to make you PROVE everything. He discourages memorizing and believes in "organic" learning. Tests are hard.
pretty good class.
Thumbs up!

Spinu is very thorough and often goes beyond the textbook.  His website is maintained and includes notes and additionalproblems.  Also, he responds to emails punctually. He is a really nice person and unbelievably intelligent.  But, he makes his tests fairly difficult. Fortunately, he understands that, and distributes grades accordingly. best prof!
Great lecturer, his explinations were usually very clear and his tests were fair. He was the reason that I took Calc III.

spinu's a great professor and he genuinely cares whether you understand the material or not (just go to his office hours!). i like his teaching style but i have to admit calculus is tough. some people just expect college to be nothing but fun, well tough luck cause if it were all so easy it wouldn't be worth much, would it?

granted, I took Calc II two years ago, but I remember Spinu being a great lecturer. He was difficult to understand at first, but I found that when I took good notes, and then went back over them carefully, i realized that he explained everything so clearly, much better than the books. It took a bit of effort, but in the end, I really learned calc.

I swear I had a different Florin Spinu for a teacher.  He was nearly impossible to understand, and did all his lectures backwards (did problems before he lectured on the topic) which made lecture really hard to follow.  The averages on his exams were Fs, so he just curved everyone up to a B or an A-not bad but no one learned any calc!!!!!
This guy is very smart, gices decent lectures, and is EXTREMELY helpful during office hours.
approachable and very helpful

Spinu's hot. Love his accent, his clothes (haha except the shoes, those pumps have got to go), great body, so cute you actually want to go to lecture and listen to calculus lectures-- "minous". He also happens to be brilliant...young grad from amazing schools and teaching at Hopkins!
great guy.. definitely recommend him.. very helpful during office hours as well.. and i aced the midterm :p
i'm giving "MINOUS" points!
is a brilliant mathematician, but still new at teaching. lectures are fast paced and sometimes hard to follow

Extremely disorganized lectures. Before this class, I had never had a lecture that was more confusing than the written textbook--now I have. He takes simple, often already known concepts, and buries them in such deep layers of mathematical jargon you would already have to be a master of Calculus to understand him.

I've had Professor Spruck for two math classes now. His lectures are thorough and well-paced, and I never felt lost during lecture, regardless of the size of class. If I ever did get confused, he happily and readily answered my questions.

The professor is nice and good with sharing class materials but his lectures are not very organized. The quizzes and exams are quite straightforward but he is a very mean grader(!!!). A lot of students ended up with C or below.

he doesn't know how to teach and he's very disorganized. Doesn't explain anything in depth and would sometimes write a topic and forget about it, only to go to the next topic. Being in lecture made it harder to understand material than learning on my own. Also the only calc 3 professor in recent years to curve to a B/B- rather than an A.
Very easy-going, wants you to learn, is pretty lenient about exams.
He's smart and helpful, but you need to be attentive in the classes to fully understand what he talks about. The class is hard but useful.

Seriously a horrible teacher.  But somehow lecture is still helpful.  At first I stopped going because I thought it was a waste of time, but after I started going to lecture I did really well.  Use the learning den!

Nice guy, but a horrible professor. He does know what he's talking about, but he's so obsessed with math that he does not clearly explain anything. The Marsden Vector calc book is equally useless, and the tests/ quizzes are definitely harder than other teacher's calc 3 stuff. Watch the MIT OCW videos and hope you get an easy TA.
run.
Dear god, this guy was an IDIOT. ABSOLUTE..... ugh!!!!!!   WORST proffessor I've ever had at Hopkins. Could not teach AT ALL. Unorganized, NOT helpful... avoid!
ahahaha, stooge...
complete stooge.

I know a lot of people hate him, but I like him for some reason. He really inspired me to be rich and successful, and what he said is actually useful in the real world. Quiz are all short answers but he graded them loosely. Plus, the question repeats all the time, so it is nice.

The worst instructor!!!! Please try to avoid taking his lecture. He only talks about himself and his stories without teaching anything during lectures.  The only related to knowledge he does during lectures is reading the slides. Terrible experience!!!!!!!!!!!
I'm a international student from China in his M&A class and he dont want to teach anything, just talk.
Try anything to avoid him. Teach nothing in the class.

If you ask him for extra credit, he will simply tell you that your papers will be graded "as is." Miss three classes and he will drop you. Warns you, saying "are here to work, or stare at the skies" if you're caught off guard. He told one student this, and he ended up getting cursed out and his eyebrows insulted in the process. Left us shook still.
he cool
He's a down to earth guy, love his class. His ideology is clear and leaves you thinking about your own life at the end of class. && yes that accent and jeans just make it easyier to pay attention! ;)
I love Marius!

Intro to Bioethics... ever seen Grey's Anatomy? He's reminded me of Alex Karev since day one. And yes, he is that arrogant. On the flip side, most sections were cohesive and he definitely progressed over the course of the year.
Ih ih, great TA, nice, helpful, very cute accent, and those jeans.... :)

lots of work to do. the way too much. Josh is brand new for teaching, that means he really doesn't know how to teach. just don't take this class. study ios dev by your self online. you will find better study resources. if you just want to take this course for credit? be prepared you already have ios dev experiences. worst ever

Josh knows his stuff but his course lacks structure and clarity. Be prepared to do a lot of independent research. 95% of what I learned about iOS (Swift and XCode) came from online research. The assignments are either super easy or insanely difficult. He grades hard and tends to drone in class. In all fairness this was his first time teaching.
Great teacher. I can recommend my friends to take his courses.
I would love to take another class from Professor Stephens, but I don't think my GPA can handle it.

Weekly lectures are hours long. Does not give any direction on assignments write a 5 page research paper thats all you get. IF he answers your emails its days if not weeks later and is full of excuses as to why. Grammar is more important than scientific content. Slow to grade, and cant keep up with his own syllabus. 100% regret taking him.
Tough professor. Even calling her professsor by mistake instead of doctor could receive a warning by her. Late for handling assignment for two minutes resulted in no score for it.
tough professor
She's really cool! She has a lot of inciteful things to say and really got the class talking. She requires a fair amount of writing, but is a pretty even grader. Well worth taking.

Professor Suk is etremely passionate about her work. But much more importantly she is comitted to seeing that her students understand the material which is an extremely hard task to accomplish when you are working a level as high as hers. It was my most influential class of the semester and it made me reevaluatethewayIpercieve theworld.TAKEHERCLASS
This is one Professor that will stun you with her intellect and wit. She will challenge your notions of reality and perception. Her class is a pure mind orgasm!
Really a great professor.  Goes out of way to help us out of class on papers.  Class material was rough, but she helped me through it.

Nice professor, easy class. He has a pretty thick accent, which makes it hard to understand his lectures, so just read the board and look at what he writes. He practically lectures straight from the book and his tests are identical to his homework. He's also probably the only math prof who doesn't care about proofs, which is a HUGE win in my book.

Nice professor, easy class. He has a pretty thick accent, which makes it hard to understand his lectures, so just read the board and look at what he writes. He practically lectures straight from the book and his tests are identical to his homework. He's also probably the only math prof who doesn't care about proofs, which is a HUGE win in my book.

Dr. Liming Sun was a great professor for Calc II Bio. His lectures were very clear and straightforward. Additionally, he was always accessible and helpful after class and during office hours. His class has a pretty tough curve (only 30% of the class can get an A), but I've heard that this is more of a departmental decision.

Professor Liming's lectures were very helpful and he divided them into sections correlated with the textbook. His exams were very very fair; if you study his lectures and understand all the homework and quiz questions, you will get an A. Very sweet approachable guy

Liming is a great professor. He class can be a little fast paced at times, but if you approach him with questions after class, he is always glad to help. He seems to be always in a good quirky mood and is a great math teacher especially for freshman who benefit fro a down to earth type of guy.

Liming is a solid professor, he is kinda silly and adorable in lecture which makes you really appreciate him. He gives great study material for his exams. slightly tough grader but you can definitely pass his classes if you do the work he assigns and listen to the tips he gives for exams.

Perhaps in person he is a better teacher - online class with him was a nightmare. Expect tests that are ridiculous in difficulty on material barely brushed over in class. Entirely over reliant on Flipit (which itself is hard to learn from). Only saving grace is that the class is graded on a *heavy* curve.
Prof. Swartz laughs at students that ask questions in class. His tests are ridiculously hard. Students are not prepared for homework and test questions as he is over reliant on FlipItPhysics,

Although his teaching abilities are perfectly fine, Professor Swartz is just not a nice person in general and it really shows in the classroom. I felt that he was unnecessarily and inappropriately mean to students at times and his behavior was quite unwarranted.
GREAT teacher.  You will learn a lot from him.  I would most definitely recommend his class to people I know.

Pathetic excuse for a teacher. His teaching methods are completely ineffective, which is a huge concern for a subject like physics. His lectures focus too little on important details on physics concepts, instead focusing on lengthy and ultimately useless derivations. He uses FlipItPhysics to attempt to supplement his poor job, but it isn't enough.
You really can't see him unless you make an appointment with him, but he's a pretty OK professor, so the TA really determines the class experience. There is a pretty good curve for labs.
He doesn't do much with the lab class as is made clear but if you get to know him personally he's incredibly nice, helpful and very easy to get along with. Great guy.
Never saw him except for first day of first semester (of two). Seemed fine. Easy class. TAs were great
Availible for after hours help... What you seek is what you get.
He's not hard or easy... he teaches physics... but he is incredibly helpful
Great Prof!
Prof Swartz is one of the coolest people ever.
No Comments
this guys lectures at warp speed. and wastes time with derivations. curves ugly.
Teaches off transparencies, uses the Web as an excuse for too-fast lectures

He's a very nice guy, ALWAYS willing to help, and very intelligent. However, he is an awful lecturer. His thick accent is only one reason for this. He speaks incredibly fast and his demeanor during lecture makes him unapproachable, so that you are afraid to ask questions.

Definitely an amazing professor. I took her class before even starting my freshman year of college and she was so accommodating to my (and my peers) situation! She was also a very interesting person and it was clear she was dedicated to math.
Professor Sui is very accommodating and cares about the understanding of her students. She constantly ensures the information "makes sense". Her office hours are helpful and laid back.
She was very informative during office hours and very funny. She wants to help you to understand the information.

Sui Tang is the worst professor I've had at Hopkins. Her lectures are terrible and non-informative, her TAs are unhelpful and don't make things clear, and her final exam was by far the most unfair test I have ever taken. A class average in the 40s in Calculus II is embarrassing and reflects poorly on her as a teacher. Avoid her class at all cost!

Fun professor, humorous anecdotes, great use of memes. I feel like he genuinely cared for the wellbeing of his students. I appreciated the incorporation of themes like gender and colonialism. Lots of readings, some were hard, but the professor was available to help. Definitely expects participation. Easy grader if you show up and express interest.

Fun professor, humorous anecdotes, great use of memes. I feel like he genuinely cared for the wellbeing of his students. I appreciated the incorporation of themes like gender and colonialism. Lots of readings, some were hard, but the professor was available to help. Definitely expects participation. Easy grader if you show up and express interest.

I loved this class with Professor Taylor. His lectures were easy to follow, he was very passionate about the subject, and his awkward humor was very endearing. If you go to class and do the readings and put in the effort its an easy A. I'm not an art student but it was a fun class for humanities requirement and surprisingly interesting.

Oleg's lectures are completely useless. His class is a huge waste of time. His tests and grading system are a mystery to everyone. Basically he screwed up because he made the first two exams really easy so there was no curve, and then the last one was hard, so he didn't get his desired bell curve. The final distrubution (by points) was tiny.
Great class! Interesting, engaging lectures that relate the material to real-life applications. Great professor as well. Easy to talk to, has a good sense of humor, and cares about students' success.
Great class! Interesting, engaging lectures that relate the material to real-life applications. Great professor as well. Easy to talk to, has a good sense of humor, and cares about students' success.

Funny guy, but I didn't learn much in lecture. As long as you read the book and do the homework, it's pretty easy (provided you don't lose your notecard full of equations like I did right before the final).
Class is somewhat helpful.  Pretty much read the book and understand the practice problems and you will do fine.  Good guy though
The class is well organized, and tests are very fair.
Good organization, sense of humor.

he sits while teaching, hardly ever does practice problems, completely didn't care about teaching and was more interested about his research.  The tests were not bad if you went to review sessions no thanks to him, the TAs were decent.  It is possible to get a B or above by going to reviews and ignoring his lectures

As someone else mentioned, he is a charming professor. The material is not easy, but he is very fair and it is possible to pull off a good final average if you work hard. He seems to love teaching and you can tell that he really wants you to succeed. His lectures are very well prepared, but reading and practicing are more important for the tests.

demonstrates/shows more than he teaches, but i liked the in-class demonstrations. either way, he basically teaches from the book so as long as you at least look over the slides and read the book and do problems, it's fine. hw was easier than tests (which honestly were not too hard at all), but questions on test seemed to come out of left field.
Nice

He is so useless and his tests come out of nowhere. His lectures consist of higher level conceptual things. Making class mandatory is unnecessary and his CPS policy is flaky and unreliable. The only thing that saved me was the review session before the exam.
No Comments
Class is boring, and he makes things seem more difficult than it is. Sits down the whole time teaching so he's not engaging. He can't teach well but he knows his stuff. At least he's charming.

I LOVED HIM!!! You dont really have to attend the lectures since they are all online, but he is a wonderful lecturer which makes going to class not bad. You can tell that he really loves what he does. Also the tests are bad if you learn the information, which includes the book! Overall my favorite teacher at hopkins thus far!

He's a great guy that is extremely reputable in the field that he works in and knows his stuff.  If you look him up he's on many truly amazing publications.  The courses he teaches are already interesting, but if you don't think so at first, I think you should just give it time and understand that he has a great passion for this field for a reason.

He's a really great teacher. Lectures while are pointless to attend bc everything is on Webct are fun. His tests are specific. It's hard to know what to study...so just study everything. Don't fall behind on the reading. Learn the specifics. :)

As someone else commented, he does mostly go through his slides, which are on webct.  He's an interesting lecturer though and tells a bunch of fun stories.  Also, he's just a genuinely nice guy who really wants to help you learn.  His tests aren't easy, but it's always super clear what you need to know.  He's taught my favorite classes at Hopkins!
fun lecturer.  tests were specific, but after you fail the first one, you'll ace the next 2 and get a b.  pay attention to the nerves of the thorax.  fun and interesting but tests hard.

doesn't really teach as simply goes through his powerpoint, which is on webct, thereby making going to lecture, pointless. is a really nice guy who knows what he's doing and has been to a lot of places, but his teaching (at least for this class) is very tedious
Fantastic professor. Great sense of humor and brilliant lectures! Don't leave Hopkins without taking one of his classes!
No Comments
"What makes great people great is not that they're always great, its that they're sometimes great.  Some people are never great.  That's just how it works." - Zlatko
AMAZING!!!!!!!
Great professor. Really emphasizes thinking outside the box and being creative. Challenges you to think critically and differently. A little bit crazy but truly one of a kind.
Great professor. Really emphasizes thinking outside the box and being creative. Challenges you to think critically and differently. A little bit crazy but truly one of a kind.
One of the best professors I had.
Thakor acts like he hates the class, but in the end, he is a nice guy.
very very bad person
Crazy amounts of homework required. Difficult exams.

Mark Thompson's class on literary theory was phenomenal. The reading syllabus has something for everyone. Thompson's dissections of the assigned texts will absolutely blow your mind and your small class bonds over intellectual discussions. The workload is very light(most of the time skimming a reading is fine)and the class is extremely engaging.

Fantastic teacher. He was in the US National Security Council, responsible for South Asia - he knew his India/Pak course backwards. Inspires a lot of interest in the subject, has a remarkable sense of humor and is always very helpful. Best experience at Hopkins so far!

Phenomenal teacher. Has an ability to transform the material into a cohesive and linear narrative that is both interesting and easy to understand. I have had him for both US Foreign Policy since 1945 and Foreign Relations of India and Pakistan and they have been two of the most interesting and informative classes I have taken at Hopkins.
Great Professor, easy class,

Nice old guy.  He's amazing, his lectures are not only informative, interesting, and funny: but they include a personal aspect that comes from his own in depth experience in the subject matter and makes you think and CARE about what happens in the US and the rest of the world.  Great classes, both of them (S. Asia IR and US FP since 1945).
His real world experience and humor really adds to the class. Great class for IR majors interested in Asian issues.

Professor Sunita is pretty cool but the subject matter is pretty dry. The ideas that she goes over aren't really difficult at all but may be difficult for incoming freshman. What I find rather funny is that you can get a good grade in this class with absolutely no knowledge in chemistry. 80% of this course is computational meaning its mostly math.
Hard midterms and exams. gives too much work and quizzes. Tolman/karlin is better

Dr Sunita is a very informative lecturer. Others have said that her quizzes/exams are very hard, but theyre very similar to those given in class, so I think theyve been fair. She makes some computational errors during lecture and does move quickly through the dense topics, but since the lectures are recorded, I can go back and watch them again.

Professor Sunita is pretty cool but the subject matter is pretty dry. The ideas that she goes over aren't really difficult at all but may be difficult for incoming freshman. What I find rather funny is that you can get a good grade in this class with absolutely no knowledge in chemistry. 80% of this course is computational meaning its mostly math.

Mediocre Professor and her lecturing has gotten much worse in the past few years. She will practically mess up her calculations for almost every problem in class. She's goes too slow on the easiest topics and zooms through the harder topics. Be wary of Thermo; she's struggles to teach that unit. Overall, just don't slack off and you can get the A.
She is extremely willing to help, I would strongly recommend going to her office hours. As long as you work hard it's pretty easy to get an A
Solid teaching. Went to slow at the beginning and too fast at the end but otherwise lectures very well
She is AWESOME!!

Dr. Sunita is truly amazing. She really wants students to do well but you need to work for your grade. She is accessible outside of class. I feel like the people who rate her poorly are those who feel entitled to getting an A or B in this type of class. Chemistry is hard, we get it. But you are going to have to work extremely hard to get a good gra
Study hard and meet with sunita often and you'll do great! If you can, take this class over the summer- the class size is much smaller and it's easier to do well!
Good lecturer, pretty good representation of intro level chem class. Fair tests and very accessible through office hours.

Only had her for chem lab. She doesn't do much in lab, but if you study and understand the chemistry concepts from lecture (whoever you have) and practice the problems, you can ace it. Takes a lot of effort that isn't worth a 1-credit class though.

I've seen multiple negative reviews here that have been removed.... This class brought so much anxiety to my first year of college. The lectures are nearly impossible to follow and the exams are unbelievably difficult for someone who has never taken chemistry before. Avoid if you can

Professor Sunita is extremely kind, nice, and generous. She is a very fair grader. If you put in the work, go to office hours, and pay attention, then an A is feasible. I really enjoyed having her as a professor this semester. She definitely made me feel welcome. 10/10

The tests are fair and lots of practice problems and worksheets are available. Prof. Sunita works through a lot of problems on the board in class, which is helpful, and she posts lecture slides online as well. She is a caring professor and is helpful during office hours.
Take Goldberg unless you're really into chem

I had Prof. Sunita for chem 1 and chem 2. She is very helpful, especially in office hours. Tests look exactly like in-class problems, and both chem 1 and 2 are easy A's if you pay attention//try at all. Con: her class full of entitled freshmen who expect A's for no work/disrespect her/talk through class--I think that's why her rating is low.

For chem II she started out as a really great lecturer but as the year went on we would cram a bunch of topics into one lecture and breeze through them without going in depth much. Honestly just do every single worksheet/powerpoint problem and make a solid cheat sheet and you'll be good on the midterms/final. Easy A if you're above the average
Take Goldberg instead for the easier grade but learn more .
Homework is straightforward, tests are challenging, but she's extremely helpful during office hours (she wants you to succeed in her class). The class curve isn't the greatest.
Good teacher, tough grader.

Tifft is so nice! I took biochemistry online with her and she made it so much more bearable. She simplifies concepts, regularly checks Piazza, and is super helpful in office hours. I will be taking another class with her next semester. I just wish the other biochem profs followed her example because she is truly amazing. Not a hard class either!

Tifft is so nice! I took biochemistry online with her and she made it so much more bearable. She simplifies concepts, regularly checks Piazza, and is super helpful in office hours. I will be taking another class with her next semester. I just wish the other biochem profs followed her example because she is truly amazing. Not a hard class either!
The classes are very well structured. I'm just not good at biochemistry...

Dr. Tilli is a decent lecturer, explains the biochemical pathways well. But, I found that what she stressed in class was not always to the level of detail that she expected on the exams. Some things seemed as if we didn't need to know them at all, and they were a large portion of the test. She is awesome in office hours and lab though!
Im a terrible writer, but Robert is awesome at seeing what you do well and helping you fix what you need to work on. I recommend this class to everyone!
Teacher understands the material well but has real trouble conveying it to students. Material is quite dense.
Very nice person and good teacher.

OMG SERIOUSLY THE BIGGEST WORST TEACHER AT JH!!!!! SHE SHOULD GET FIRED SHE HAS NO SENSE OF KNOWLEDGE AND RAMBLES ON ABOUT NONSENSE.. SERIOUSLY ONE OF THE WORST TEACHERS AT JHU!! NEVER TAKE HER..!!! SHE COMPLAINS TOO MUCH ABOUT LIFE.. SHES SO FAKE AND JUST OVER ALL UGGHHH .. SERIOUSLY DONT TAKE HER!!!!!!!!

Solid professor. Focuses a on quantitative problems over qualitative on tests. Provided all necessary formulas on all tests. Three midterms and Final make vast majority of grade. Practice problems and Sapling are the keys to success.

Solid professor. Focuses a on quantitative problems over qualitative on tests. Provided all necessary formulas on all tests. Three midterms and Final make vast majority of grade. Practice problems and Sapling are the keys to success.

Dr. Tolman isn't a good lecturer and is new to Intro to Chem so he's not the best at explaining things for beginners. Averages were generally low but this is mostly a freshman class so people are adjusting. His test questions could be hard. Read the textbook but don't buy it. Rent it from Amazon. Redo saplings for exam practice and do his review.

Confusing, boring lectures full of unnecessary details with little/no time do actually do clicker questions. The exams are a surprise since so much information given in lectures it's hard to know what you will be tested on. Tolman overly complicates intro Chem. if possible, take someone else.

The grading for this class is ridiculous! For example, I had misread a question on the final and put my answer for part c in the wrong spot. He was not understanding at all and eagerly did not give me back any points. I was one point away from earning an A! His responses on Piazza are also VERY rude! If you can get another professor, DO IT!
He is very moody. Be prepared to see very different sides of him depending on the day and/or semester. Exams were hit or miss. A lot more material in the class than is possible to be tested on.

Lectures were decent. Sometimes, they missed the bigger picture of why we were doing something, but going to office hours helped a lot. Dr. Torcaso is great, but the TAs for this course are excellent. The exams tended to be fair. Seriously though, go to office hours!
While his class was very hard, I greatly appreciate how he cares for his students.
Great professor cares about your grade if you care

Torcaso is a great lecturer. And Math subjects are really hard to teach as lectures. But Torcaso can do it. He will make sure you understand the material. Took a class with him over the summer and he was fantastic. I don't see the negative comments below as being relateable in my experience.  Lots of assignments, in class and homework - great prof!

At first I was thinking about dropping this course but I'm so happy that I did not drop it! The lectures are very helpful, make sure you take good notes. The handwritten notes by the professor are also good materials to study. Textbooks are okay but it's not mandatory to read them. The exams are very fair, not hard if you understand the lectures.

Some people say he's a nice guy, some people say he was rude, mean, and unnaproachable. I saw both sides. On the whole he didn't seem very interested in us. There was way too much homework for it to count for such a low percentage of the overall grade. The tests had wordy questions. ZERO partial credit. Felt like he was just trying to dock points.

I don't know why everyone said he cares about his students - he literally screamed at this one girl for no reason,and  snorted dismissively while handing back tests to the students that apparently didn't do well. I came out with an okay understanding of stats and better understanding that there are rude people out there.

If you only expect to memorize formulas you won't do well. Tests are based more on understanding than memorization and are structured around examples given in class. Examples are real world applications, providing an intuition for the material. I went to office hours often and he was always very helpful and approachable.
not helpful at office hours, teaches the class content in a confusing and incoherent way, does not give partial points in exams, makes his own questions that are wordy and unnecessarily complicated
His class is fairly easy, however, he does not curve at all and does not care about his students whatsoever. His tests get progressively harder throughout the semester.

Horrible.Ignore other ratings. His class does not have a curve and the avg is like a C-. Do not take it if you don't have to. Book is useless. Study the lecture notes and do all/study over the homework. Then you might do ok. Otherwise prepare to get destroyed.
i really hated this guy. He didnt teach the class well, and the homeworks did not repressent the exams well.

Dr. Torcaso is one of the best professors I've had here. He explains all of the concepts really well and is genuinely interested in helping his students learn. After the last class, he even thanked me for working hard; he's a really nice, quirky person, who also does a really good job teaching the class.
A really nice guy, but class is pretty boring because of the easy material.
Teaches well from experience. Better than most LADE teachers. I wish that I had gone to class more, but I did okay without going. Section is pretty useless. He is interested in his subject
Fred is the best teacher I ever had. He makes difficult subjects seem crystal clear, easy.
Great guy, very clear. Boring class, though. TA's are important.
Good teacher but the subject is too easy to not teach well. The class is so boring and only half the people show up except on Fridays, when we turn in HW. YOu learn better from TA's
Great teacher.  He is really clear to understand nad is easy to approach.  It's orgo though, so what can you expect.
The class sucked. Timed 100 question test on a stupid manual. 120 minutes to take the test.

Not helpful when approached. Teaching style favors the hands-off approach.  100 question multiple choice test with content based solely on 380 pages from an ANSI manual.  Unimpressed with knowledge.  Just teaches with "tidbits" of information.  Severely lacking enough for me to withdraw and pursue my degree elsewhere.

THIS IS THE WORST CLASS I HAVE EVER TAKEN. My dude is just not very good at teaching. Period. He expects too much for his level of teaching. The material is pretty ridiculous too so that doesn't help.
somewhat decently mediocre okayish lecturer but his exams are very unfair, he says their not, but they are with out a doubt. ( I got a decent grade too so im not just saying that)

Heard HORROR stories about Tovar's orgo class, but honestly for the first time ever  I enjoyed chemistry. Sure it was a tough class and sure he could have done more to make it easier (homework and quizzes to make sure we stayed on top of material) but he was fair, and genuinely seemed to enjoy teaching the material.

Worst professor I've ever had, probably ever will have. I go to class with a solid idea of a concept, and leave confused. Unclear grading scale, very difficult to understand, and his entire class is centered around a book. Get prepared to spend an average of two hours daily on this class. Gives no practice problems with relation to exam problems

He's a very smart man, but literally the worst professor I've ever had. Spends an entire lecture on one example and then tells you to read the book. Doesn't actually teach anything. 1/10 would not recommend.

Gets a bad rap, but coming from someone who had to take Orgo 1 twice, he's actually great. Follows the textbook in the order the author wrote it, exactly section by section, so it's always easy to know what you need to know (which is not quite the case with Falzone and Greenberg). Tests were hard but rarely unfair. He's hilarious and very nice.

Townsend is the best chemistry teacher I've ever had. He is very approachable and explains the reasoning behind reactions and mechanisms. In retrospect his tests were pretty easy and as long as put in the work you'll do well. I hope he teaches Orgo II.
Teaches directly from the book. He is a great prof. who loves the material, and what he does. He made me want to be a chemistry major. If you get the chance definitely take a class with him.
Great Professor. He's helpful in office hours and conducts fascinating research. Teaches and tests directly from the textbook. If you put in the time you can get a good grade.

Inspiring, brilliant, interesting, and hilarious. IDK where all the hate for this guy comes from. Maybe its the sonic boom I hear from his jokes going over everyone's head. Talk to him. He will make you love chemistry.

Dr. Townsend is a great professor who writes extremely fair tests that enable you to apply the concepts well.
